editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We provide an outline of the proof of the Donovan--Wemyss Conjecture in the context of the Homological Minimal Model Program for threefolds. The proof relies on results of August, of Hua and the second-named author, Wemyss, and on the Derived Auslander--Iyama Correspondence -- a recent result by the first- and third-named authors.

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We work over a perfect field. Recent work of the third-named author established a Derived Auslander Correspondence that relates finite-dimensional self-injective algebras that are twisted $3$-periodic to algebraic triangulated categories of finite type. Moreover, the aforementioned work also shows that the latter triangulated categories admit a unique differential graded enhancement. In this article we prove a higher-dimensional version of this result that, given an integer $d\geq1$, relates twisted $(d+2)$-periodic algebras to algebraic triangulated categories with a $d\mathbb{Z}$-cluster tilting object. We also show that the latter triangulated categories admit a unique differential graded enhancement. Our result yields recognition theorems for interesting algebraic triangulated categories, such as the Amiot cluster category of a self-injective quiver with potential in the sense of Herschend and Iyama and, more generally, the Amiot-Guo-Keller cluster category associated with a $d$-representation finite algebra in the sense of Iyama and Oppermann. As an application of our result, we obtain infinitely many triangulated categories with a unique differential graded enhancement that is not strongly unique. In the appendix, B. Keller explains how -- combined with crucial results of August and Hua-Keller -- our main result yields the last key ingredient to prove the Donovan-Wemyss Conjecture in the context of the Homological Minimal Model Program for threefolds.

msc.text: Homotopical algebra, Quillen model categories, derivators

title.title: The Derived Auslander-Iyama Correspondence

editorial_contributions.text:
Model categories of operads have been considered in the symmetric case by \textit{V. Hinich} [Commun. Algebra 25, No.~10, 3291--3323 (1997; Zbl 0894.18008)] and \textit{C. Berger} and \textit{I. Moerdijk} [Comment. Math. Helv. 78, No.~4, 805--831 (2003; Zbl 1041.18011)] They showed that under certain hypotheses, the category of operads can be given a model category structure.

This paper considers the nonsymmetric case. This has previously been considered by \textit{J. E. Harper} [J. Pure Appl. Algebra 214, No.~8, 1407--1434 (2010; Zbl 1231.55011)]; the present work is a more general setting. This paper proves that under the much milder condition of the standard monoid axiom of \textit{S. Schwede} and \textit{B. E. Shipley} [Proc. Lond. Math. Soc., III. Ser. 80, No.~2, 491--511 (2000; Zbl 1026.18004)], the category of nonsymmetric operads is a cofibrantly generated model category where the weak equivalences and fibrations are defined levelwise. The paper propves these by very explicit analysis of the structure of properties of pushouts of operads.

Similarly, algebras in a monoidal model category satisfying the monoid axiom are shown to be a cofibrantly generated model category. The author concludes by applying this framework to show that in many standard examples, the homotopy theory of enriched categories coincides with the homotopy of \(A_{\infty}\)-categories.

title.title: Homotopy theory of nonsymmetric operads

editorial_contributions.text:
Homotopy categories, track categories are categories enriched by groupoids. We are in the 2-category of abelian track categories, pseudofunctors and pseudonatural transformations. 

The translation cohomology is introduced in order to classify endomorphisms in the previous 2-category. The obstruction theory here developed is defined in the Baues-Wirsching cohomology of categories. 

Some element of a third cohomology of \({\mathcal A}\) vanishes if and only if there exists a pseudofunctor \({\mathcal A}\to {\mathcal B}\) satisfying some property. An interpretation of this obstruction is given in terms of exact sequences for functors and linear extensions of categories.

title.title: The homotopy category of pseudofunctors and translation cohomology

editorial_contributions.text: Like the computation of homotopy groups of spheres in low dimensions uses Toda brackets (secondary operations defined by pasting tracks, i.e., homotopy classes of homotopies), secondary homotopy groups supplement the structure of classical homotopy groups. Investigating the algebraic nature of tracks, secondary (or 2-dimensional) groups appear and can be described in terms of crossed modules. The topological and functorial point of view leads to important new results. The crucial topological tool for the construction is the Hopf invariant for tracks which generalizes the classical one for maps. One has a 2-functor on the groupoid-enriched category of pointed spaces compatible with fiber sequences, suspensions and loop spaces.

editorial_contributions.text:
The authors provide a (theoretical) description for cohomologically triangulated categories as triples \(({\mathcal A}, t,
abla)\), where \(\mathcal A\) is an additive category which is endowed with an additive equivalence \(t:{\mathcal A}	o {\mathcal A}\) and a homology class \(
abla\) in \(H^{3}({\mathcal A},t)\). 

The main result in the first part of the paper is Theorem 2.15: Let \(({\mathcal B},s)\) and \(({\mathcal C},r)\) be good translation track categories representing the same cohomology class in \(H^{3}({\mathcal A},t)\). Then \(({\mathcal B},s)\) admits a structure of (pre)triangulated category iff \(({\mathcal C},r)\) does. Using this theorem it is proved that if \(({\mathcal A}, t,
abla)\) is a cohomologically (pre)triangulated category and \(\mathcal{E}_{
abla}\) is the class of small \(
abla\)-triangles then \(({\mathcal A}, t,\mathcal{E}_
abla)\) is a (pre)triangulated category. 

In the end of the paper the octahedral axiom is proved for cohomologically triangulated categories.

title.title: Cohomologically triangulated categories. I

editorial_contributions.text:
[For part I, see \textit{H.-J. Baues} and \textit{F. Muro}, J. K-Theory 1, No.~1, 3--48 (2008; Zbl 1152.18006).]

In the main result of this interesting paper the authors characterize cohomologically triangulated categories in a pure cohomologically way, i.e., without using representations by track categories and pseudofunctors for translation cohomology classes. This result is a consequence of other very useful characterizations of cohomologically pretriangulated categories and of cohomologically triangulated categories. These results are illustrated by an interesting example.

editorial_contributions.text: The authors introduce secondary homotopy groups for symmetric spectra, forming a lax symmetric monoidal functor \(\pi_{*,*}\). In particular, let \(R\) be a ring spectrum; then \(\pi_{*,*}R\) has the structure of a secondary ring; the homology of \(\pi_{*,*}R\) is the ordinary homotopy ring \(\pi_* R\); triple Massey products in in \(\pi_{*,*}R\) coincide with triple Toda brackets in \(\pi_* R\); one can construct new derivations of \(\pi_* R\). For a commutative ring spectrum \(Q\), the cup-one operation in \(\pi_* Q\) is obtained from a construction in \(\pi_{*,*}Q\).

title.title: The algebra of secondary homotopy operations in ring spectra

editorial_contributions.text:
Associahedra are polytopes first introduced by Stasheff to model loop spaces, and together form a topological operad whose algebras are \(A_\infty\)-spaces, which have homotopy associative multiplication. Taking cellular chains on this operad gives a differential graded operad whose algebras are \(A_\infty\)-algebras. However, in both the topological and differential graded settings, it is assumed that units are strict. The question of whether units can be taken to be homotopy coherent was taken up by Fukaya, Oh, Ohta, and Ono [\textit{K. Fukaya} et al., Lagrangian intersection Floer theory. Anomaly and obstruction. I. Providence, RI: American Mathematical Society (AMS); Somerville, MA: International Press (2009; Zbl 1181.53002); Lagrangian intersection Floer theory. Anomaly and obstruction. II. Providence, RI: American Mathematical Society (AMS); Somerville, MA: International Press (2009; Zbl 1181.53003)] in the differential graded setting in their work on symplectic geometry, and they defined an operad whose algebras have homotopy coherent unit.

In this paper, the authors seek to find a topological analogue, or a topological operad whose algebras are \(A_\infty\)-spaces with homotopy coherent, rather than strict, unit. They generalize the Boardman-Vogt cubical subdivision approach to associahedra to give a definition of unital associahedra using planar rooted trees. Then they show that these spaces can be defined cellularly, although they can no longer be realized as polytopes. Finally, they prove that taking cellular chains on the resulting operad recovers the differential graded operad of Fukaya-Oh-Ohno-Ono.

The diagrams in the paper are particularly helpful with lots of illustrations of operations on trees, and then several color pictures of unital associahedra.

title.title: Unital associahedra

editorial_contributions.text:
The secondary homotopy groups \(\Pi_{n,*} X\) of a space \(X\) are quadratic pair modules which form a model for \((n-1)\)-connected \((n+1)\)-types. They are a sort of crossed modules and in particular there is a group homomorphism \(\Pi_{n,1} X \rightarrow \Pi_{n,0} X\) with kernel \(\pi_n X\) and cokernel \(\pi_{n+1} X\) when \(n \geq 3\). These objects have been studied by the authors in [Forum Math. 20, No. 4, 631--677 (2008; Zbl 1158.18004)].

The symmetric group \(Sym(n)\) acts on the sphere \(S^n = S^1 \wedge \dots \wedge S^1\) by permutation of coordinates and there is a central extension by a cyclic group of order \(2\) acting on \(\Pi_{n,*} X\), as crossed modules. This extension is classified in \(H^2(Sym(n); \mathbb F_2)\) by the second Stiefel-Whitney class of the fiber bundle defined by the obvious representation of \(Sym(n)\) in \(O_n(\mathbb R)\). It is called ``symmetric track group'' in this article since its elements can be interpreted as certain homotopy classes of homotopies between self-maps of \(S^n\).

msc.text: Homotopy groups, general; sets of homotopy classes

title.title: The characteristic cohomology class of a triangulated category

editorial_contributions.text:
The purpose of this paper is to compare associative operads and unital associative operads in a fairly general class of model categories. The starting point is the categorical result that, in any close symmetric monoidal category \(\mathcal V\) with an initial object, the morphism from the associative operad to the unital associative operad is an epimorphism in the category of operads in \(\mathcal V\). To generalize to the model category setting, one first needs for \(\mathcal V\) to be a sufficiently nice closed symmetric monoidal model category with some appropriate axioms for the unit. Then the appropriate analogue for the theorem is that the map from the associative operad to the unital associative operad in \(\mathcal V\) to be a homotopy epimorphism.

The paper begins with a treatment of homotopy epimorphisms, which do not seem to be as well-known as the dually-defined homotopy monomorphisms. It continues with a lengthy section on operads, which in particular gives an extended description of free operads on trees. These two topics are likely to be of independent interest; the treatment of trees is perhaps more familiar in the context of dendroidal sets, but is used in an elegant way here. Later in the operad section are a number of technical results used to prove the main theorem which make use of weaker \(A_\infty\) operads and intermediate versions which the author calls \(u\)-\textit{infinity (unital) associative operads}.

The author first proves his main result for the examples where \(\mathcal V\) is the category of groupoids or \(\mathcal V\) is the category of chain complexes, using the intermediate operads defined here. From there, he proves a result which allows the conclusion of the desired map being a homotopy epimorphism to be transferred across a Quillen adjunction. This result is used first to prove the result for the examples of non-negatively graded chain complexes and simplicial sets, and from there to any closed symmetric monoidal category which has a simplicial or complicial (here meaning compatibly enriched in chain complexes) structure.

series.title: Transactions of the American Mathematical Society

title.title: Homotopy units in \(A\)-infinity algebras

editorial_contributions.text: A small functorial algebraic model is given for the 2-stage Postnikov section of the \(K\)-theory spectrum of a Waldhausen category. More specifically, a nice 2-functor \(\mathcal D_*\) is constructed from the 2-category \(\mathbb C\) of Waldhausen categories to the 2-category of ``stable quadratic modules'', so that \(\mathcal D_*\mathbb C\) gives the homotopy type of the Postnikov section of \(K\mathbb C\). And \(\mathcal D_*\mathbb C\) has a presentation in the same spirit as the presentation of \(K_1\) in \textit{A. Nenashev} [J. Pure Appl. Algebra 131, No. 2, 195--212 (1998; Zbl 0923.19001)], but now with crossed complexes. In order to capture the multiplicative structure also, the stable quadratic module needs to be enriched with an extra quadratic map \(H\). Altogether one associates to \(\mathbb C\) an exact sequence of length four, a pairing \(\langle~,~\rangle\) and the map \(H\). Along the way, the total crossed complex of a bisimplicial complex is introduced and an Eilenberg-Zilber-Cartier equivalence is established for it.

title.title: The 1-type of a Waldhausen \(K\)-theory spectrum

editorial_contributions.text:
A general notion of \(K\)-theory, for a category \({\mathcal W}\) with cofibrations and weak equivalences, was defined by Waldhausen as the homotopy groups of the loop space of a certain simplicial category \(wS.{\mathcal W}\). 

\[
K_n{\mathcal W}=\pi_n\Omega|wS.{\mathcal W}|\simeq\pi_{n+1}|wS.{\mathcal W}|
\]
 
Waldhausen \(K\)-theory generalizes the \(K\)-theory of an exact category \({\mathcal E}\), defined as homotopy groups of \(\Omega|Q{\mathcal E}|\) where \(Q{\mathcal E}\) is a category defined by Quillen.

Nenashev has given representatives for \(K_1{\mathcal E}\) which are pairs of short exact sequences on the same objects. He showed that the pairs of short exact sequences satisfy certain relations. Further, he proved that these pairs of short exact sequences together with these relations give a presentation for \(K_1{\mathcal E}\).

In this paper, the authors produce representatives for all elements in \(K_1\) of an arbitrary Waldhausen category. These representatives are close to Nenashev's representations for exact categories. They are given by pairs of weak cofiber sequences which have the same source and target. Moreover, the authors also show that these pairs of weak cofiber sequences satisfy certain generalization of Nenashev's relations.

For the entire collection see [Zbl 1147.19001].

source.source: Corti√±as, Guillermo (ed.) et al., \(K\)-theory and noncommutative geometry. Proceedings of the ICM 2006 satellite conference, Valladolid, Spain, August 31--September 6, 2006. Z√ºrich: European Mathematical Society (EMS) (ISBN 978-3-03719-060-9/hbk). EMS Series of Congress Reports, 91-115 (2008).

title.title: On \(K_1\) of a Waldhausen category

editorial_contributions.text:
The \(n\)-type of a (connected) CW complex is the homotopy type of the \(n\)th Postnikov approximation \(P_n(X)\). The suspension of \(X\) is the homotopy pushout of the diagram \(* \gets X \to *\); in words, it is the union of two cones on \(X\) along their bases. It is denoted \(\Sigma X\). In 1949, J. H. C. Whitehead introduced crossed modules, which serve as algebraic models of \(2\)-types. These can be assembled into totally free crossed complexes, which constitute a model category \textbf{H}. In 1991, Baues defined quadratic modules, which model \(3\)-types. The totally free quadratic complexes form a model category \textbf{Q}. Let \textbf{CW} denote the category of CW complexes with trivial \(0\)-skeleton and cellular maps. There are functors 
\[
 \rho : \mathbf{CW} \to \mathbf{H} \quad \text{and} \quad \sigma : \mathbf{CW} \to \widetilde{\mathbf{Q}}, 
\]
 where \(\widetilde{\mathbf{Q}}\) is the quotient of \(\mathbf{Q}\) by a certain homotopy relation. \(\rho(X)\) is an algebraic model for the \(2\)-type of \(X\), and \(\sigma(X)\) is an algebraic model for the \(3\)-type.

The main result of the paper under review constructs an algebraic functor \(\widetilde \Sigma : \mathbf{H} \to \widetilde{\mathbf{Q}}\) such that the diagram 
\[
 \begin{tikzcd} \mathbf{CW} \ar[rr,"-\Sigma"]\ar[d,"\rho" '] & & \mathbf{CW} \ar[d,"\sigma"]\\ \mathbf{H} \ar[r,"\widetilde{\Sigma}" ']& \mathbf{Q}\ar[r] & \widetilde{\mathbf Q} \end{tikzcd} 
\]
 is commutative up to natural isomorphism. Technical applications in algebra and topology are given.

series.title: Transactions of the American Mathematical Society

title.title: Suspensions of crossed and quadratic complexes, co-H-structures and applications

editorial_contributions.text: The cohomology \(H\) of \textit{H.-J. Baues} and \textit{G. Wirsching} [J. Pure Appl. Algebra 38, 187--211 (1985; Zbl 0587.18006)] of categories generalizes various known cohomology theories, such as Hochschild-Mitchell cohomology of categories, MacLane cohomology of rings, and cohomology with local coefficients of classifying spaces. It has been defined via the Baues-Wirsching complex \(F\). The paper under review considers the behaviour of \(H\) and of \(F\) under natural transformations between functors in the first variable. It is shown that \(F\) is a 2-functor into the 2-category of chain complexes. Localization and colocalization results are then derived.

series.title: Journal of Pure and Applied Algebra

title.title: On the functoriality of cohomology of categories

editorial_contributions.text: Let \({\mathcal V}\) be a combinatorial closed symmetric monoidal model category satisfying the monoid axiom of Schwede and Shipley, and let \(\text{Cat}({\mathcal V})\) be the category of small categories enriched in \({\mathcal V}\). The author constructs a combinatorial model structure on \(\text{Cat}({\mathcal V})\) in which the weak equivalences are the Dwyer--Kan equivalences, generalising essentially surjective fully faithful functors between ordinary categories. The author also considers changes of base category and gives a left properness result.

title.title: Homotopy theory of non-symmetric operads. II: Change of base category and left properness

editorial_contributions.text:
The author defines derivators and their associated \(K\)-theory. Next, one of the main theorems is that this \(K\) theory coincides with Waldhausen \(K\)-theory under certain hypotheses, namely, the author proves

Theorem 4.3.1. Let \(\mathcal{C}\) be a strongly saturated derivable Waldhausen category. Then there is a natural weak equivalence \(K(\mathcal{C})\to K^{W}(\mathbb{D}(\mathcal{C})\), where \(\mathbb{D}(\mathcal{C})\) denotes derivators of \(\mathcal{C}.\)

Moreover, the author proves that derivator \(K\)-theory is weakly equivalent to the geometric realization of Waldhausen \(K\)-theory, \(K^{W,ob}\). On the other hand, there is a comparison map \(\mu^{ob}\) from Waldhausen \(K\)-theory to derivator \(K\) theory. The second main result is that this comparison map is homotopically initial in the category with weak equivalences \(\mathbf{App}\).

title.title: \(K\)-theory of derivators revisited

series.parallel_title: Journal de l'Institut de Math√©matiques de Jussieu
series.title: Journal of the Institute of Mathematics of Jussieu

title.title: Enhanced finite triangulated categories

editorial_contributions.text:
This article gives a systematic and unified approach to \textit{determinant functors}, giving applications to answer to open questions in this area. A determinant functor on an exact category \(\mathcal{E}\) is a functor on the subcategory of isomorphisms of \(\mathcal{E}\) to a Picard groupoid (that is, a groupoid \(\mathcal{P}\) endowed with a symmetric monoidal structure \(\otimes\) such that \(X\otimes - :\mathcal{P}\to\mathcal{P}\) is an equivalence for any object \(X\) of \(\mathcal{P}\)) endowed with the following extra structure: for any short exact sequence \(X\to Y\to Z\) of \(\mathcal{E}\), a natural isomorphism \(\det(Y)\simeq\det(X)\otimes\det(Z)\), supposed to satisfy suitable coherence properties. Several variations of this notion, depending of other assumptions on the source category, are also studied in this article.

The main result of the paper (Theorem 1.5.4) gives the construction of universal determinants of various kinds by using the notion of \textit{stable quadratic module} (see \textit{H. J. Baues} [Combinatorial homotopy and 4-dimensional complexes. De Gruyter Expositions in Mathematics, 2. Berlin etc.: Walter de Gruyter (1991; Zbl 0716.55001)]). Connections with low-dimensional \(K\)-theory are investigated. This allows the authors to disprove in a quick way two conjectures of \textit{G. Maltsiniotis} (given at the end of [Categories triangulees superieures, Preprint, \url{http://www.math.jussieu.fr/~maltsin} (2006)]).

The article uses various methods: triangulated categories, homotopical algebra, simplicial objects, quadratic algebra, low-degree algebraic \(K\)-theory, monoidal categories\dots. It is probably going to become a reference on the subject, but it is difficult for the non-expert reader.

editorial_contributions.text:
This paper provides a study of one-ended locally finite CW-complexes with proper LS category \(\leq 2\). First of all the authors prove that if \((X,\alpha)\) is a properly well based proper ANR-space, then proper LS category \(X\leq 2\) if and only if \((X,\alpha)\) is a proper co-H-space.

 When \((X,\alpha)\) is a properly based polyhedron with proper LS category \(\leq 2\), then the fundamental pro-group pro-\(\pi_1(X,\alpha)\) is pro-isomorphic to a coproduct \(L\vee P\) of a free tower \(L\) by a telescopic tower \(P\). A free tower is a tower \(\cdots L_1@>i_1>> L_0\) of free groups \(L_i= \langle B_i\rangle\) such that each \(i_j: B_j\to B_{j-1}\) is an injection, and \(\bigcap B_i=\emptyset\). A telescopic tower is a tower \(\cdots\to P_1@>p_1>> P_0\) where each \(P_i= \langle D_i\rangle\) is a free group, \(D_i\subset D_{i+1}\) and the \(p_i\) are canonical projections.

 The authors deduce that two locally compact one-ended 2-dimensional connected CW complexes \(X\) and \(Y\) have the same fundamental pro-group if and only if there are spherical objects \(S^2_a\) and \(S^2_b\) such that \(X\vee S^2_a\simeq Y\vee S^2_b\).

title.title: Derived universal Massey products

editorial_contributions.text:
The main result of the paper states that the proper LS category of an eventually end-irreducible, \(\mathbb{R}^2\)-irreducible Whitehead 3-manifold is 4. 

Recall that a Whitehead manifold is a contractible open 3-manifold such that any embedded sphere bounds a ball. The manifold is \(\mathbb{R}^2\)-irreducible if any properly embedded plane \(\mathbb{R}^2\subset M\) bounds a half-space \(\mathbb{R}^2\times\mathbb{R}_+\subset M\). For a Whitehead 3-manifold, this is equivalent to \(\varprojlim\,\text{pro\,}\pi_1(X\alpha)= 0\) for any ray \(\alpha: \mathbb{R}_+\to M\). The manifold \(M\) is eventually end-irreducible if there exists an exhausting sequence \(\{M_n\}\) in \(M\) consisting of compact connected submanifolds such that there is \(n_0\) for which each surface \(\partial M\) is incompressible in \(\overline{M- M_{n_0}}\) if \(n> n_0\). This is equivalent to saying that pro-\(\pi_1(X,\alpha)\) is isomorphic to a tower whose bounding homomorphisms are injective.

title.title: The proper L-S category of Whitehead manifolds

editorial_contributions.text:
The main result of this paper gives conditions under which a monoidal model structure may be replaced by another with the same weak equivalences but in which the unit is cofibrant.

The author includes a number of examples in well-known cases of interest. The resulting model structures are generally different from standard known structures and the author remarks (p. 38) that they are generally ``not suitable to deal with commutative [monoid objects] precisely because the [unit] is cofibrant.'' The results are nevertheless interesting and presented in a straightforward manner.

title.title: Correction to: ``Homotopy theory of nonsymmetric operads. I--II''

editorial_contributions.text: Let \(A=\mathbb F_p[x^{\pm1}]\) be the graded algebra of Laurent polynomials with degree \(-1\) indeterminate \(x\), \(|x|=-1\), over the field with \(p\) elements, \(p\) a prime number, endowed with the trivial differential \(d=0\). Let \(B\) be the graded algebra over the integers \(\mathbb Z\) generated by \(e\) and \(x^{\pm1}\) in degree \(|e|=|x|=-1\) with the following additional relations, \(e^2=0\), \(ex+xe=x^2\), endowed with the degree 1 differential \(d\) defined by \(d(e)=p\), \(d(x)=0\) (notice that \(H^{\ast}(B)=A\)). In this paper the authors show that \(A\) and \(B\) have the same derivator K-theory but non-isomorphic Waldhausen K-theory. The authors also prove that Maltsiniotis's comparison and localization conjectures for derivator K-theory cannot be simultaneously true.

series.title: Journal of Pure and Applied Algebra

title.title: Cylinders for non-symmetric DG-operads via homological perturbation theory

editorial_contributions.text:
This long article is an important (both for theory and examples) contribution to the study of \textit{generalized Brown representability theorems} in (well generated) triangulated categories.

Let us remind the classical \textit{Brown representability theorem} [\textit{E. Brown}, Ann. Math. (2) 75, 467--484 (1962; Zbl 0101.40603)]: every functor from \(\mathcal Sp^{\mathrm{op}}\) (where \(\mathcal Sp\) denotes the stable homotopy category) to \(\mathbf{Ab}\) which maps exact triangles to long exact sequences and preserves products is representable. A variation of this theorem (\textit{Adams representability theorem} [\textit{J.F. Adams}, Topology 10, 185--198 (1971; Zbl 0197.19604)]) asserts that, if \(\mathcal Sp^c\) denotes the full subcategory of \(\mathcal Sp\) of compact spectra, every functor \((\mathcal Sp^c)^{\mathrm{op}}\to\mathbf{Ab}\) which maps exact triangles to long exact sequences is the restriction to \(\mathcal Sp^c\) of a representable functor; moreover, every natural transformation between such cohomological functors is induced by a map of spectra (which does not need to be unique). The extension of Brown representability theorem to other triangulated categories \(\mathcal{T}\) than \(\mathcal Sp\) is true in fairly general situations - it holds in particular for \textit{well generated} triangulated categories (an assumption which is true in the usual examples). Nevertheless, Adams representability theorem fails for a lot of well generated triangulated categories (a sufficient condition for this to hold is the category \(\mathcal{T}^c\) to be essentially countable) -- an example is the derived category of the polynomial ring \(k[x,y]\), for \(k\) a field of big enough cardinality, as shown in [\textit{J. Christensen} et al., Topology 40, No. 6, 1339--1361 (2001; Zbl 0997.18007)].

In this paper, the authors study some transfinite variations of representability. Let \(\mathcal{T}\) be a well generated triangulated category and \(\alpha\) a regular cardinal. Let us denote by \(\mathcal{T}^\alpha\) the full subcategory of \(\alpha\)-compact objects in \(\mathcal{T}\) (for the definitions, the reader can look for example at [\textit{A. Neeman}, Triangulated categories. Annals of Mathematics Studies 148. Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press (2001; Zbl 0974.18008)]). The article introduces the following properties:

\(\mathrm{ARO}_\alpha\;\) Any cohomological (that is, taking exact triangles to long exact sequences) functor \((\mathcal{T}^\alpha)^{\mathrm{op}}\to\mathbf{Ab}\) that preserves products of less than \(\alpha\) objects is the restriction to \(\mathcal{T}^\alpha\) of a representable functor on \(\mathcal{T}\).

\(\mathrm{ARM}_\alpha\;\) Any natural transformation \(\mathcal{T}(-,X)|_{\mathcal{T}^\alpha}\to\mathcal{T}(-,Y)|_{\mathcal{T}^\alpha}\) is induced by a morphism \(X\to Y\) of \(\mathcal{T}\).

For \(\alpha=\aleph_0\), these properties are the same as Adams representability.

To study properties \(\mathrm{ARO}_\alpha\) and \(\mathrm{ARM}_\alpha\), the authors take the following point of view. If \(\mathcal{C}\) is an essentially small category, let us denote by \(\mathbf{Mod}_\alpha(\mathcal{C})\) the category of functors \(\mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{op}}\to\mathbf{Ab}\) which preserve coproducts of less than \(\alpha\) objects. It is a nice abelian category; here the main case of interest is \(\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{T}^\alpha\). The restriction to this category of the representable functors on \(\mathcal{T}\) gives a functor \(S_\alpha : \mathcal{T}\to\mathbf{Mod}_\alpha(\mathcal{T}^\alpha)\); \(\mathrm{ARO}_\alpha\) means that the essential image of \(S_\alpha\) consists exactly of cohomological functors and \(\mathrm{ARM}_\alpha\) that \(S_\alpha\) is a full functor.

One of the main theoretic results of the paper, which rely on a suitable obstruction theory, which is developed in its second part, is the following. Here, pd denotes the projective dimension of an object of an abelian category.

Theorem. Corollary 2.4 and Proposition 1.2{\parindent=0.6cm\begin{itemize}\item[--] If \(F\) is an object of \(\mathbf{Mod}_\alpha(\mathcal{T}^\alpha)\) such that \(\mathrm{pd}(F)\leq 2\), then \(F\) lies in the essential image of \(S_\alpha\). \item[--] If \(X\) is an object of \(\mathcal{T}\) such that \(\mathrm{pd}(S_\alpha(X))\leq 1\), then any morphism \(S_\alpha(X)\to S_\alpha(Y)\) of \(\mathbf{Mod}_\alpha(\mathcal{T}^\alpha)\) is induced by a morphism \(X\to Y\) of \(\mathcal{T}\). \item[--] If the functor \(S_\alpha\) is full, then \(\mathrm{pd}(S_\alpha(X))\leq 1\) for each object \(X\) of \(\mathcal{T}\). 

\end{itemize}} The authors study the case of the derived category \(D(R)\) of an \textit{\(\alpha\)-coherent} ring \(R\). For the definition of this notion, and the one of the \textit{\(\alpha\)-pure global dimension} of \(R\), denoted by \(\text{pgd}_\alpha(R)\), we refer to the paper or to [\textit{C. Jensen} and \textit{H. Lenzing}, Model theoretic algebra: with particular emphasis on fields, rings, modules. Algebra, Logic and Applications, 2. New York etc.: Gordon and Breach Science Publishers (1989; Zbl 0728.03026)]. The main result is the following:

Theorem 3.3. Assume that \(\alpha>\aleph_0\) and \(R\) is an \(\alpha\)-coherent ring. If \(D(R)\) satisfies \(\mathrm{ARM}_\alpha\), then \(\text{pgd}_\alpha(R)\leq 1\). If moreover \(R\) is hereditary, then {\parindent=0.6cm\begin{itemize}\item[--] the category \(D(R)\) satisfies \(\mathrm{ARM}_\alpha\) if and only if \(\text{pgd}_\alpha(R)\leq 1\); \item[--] the category \(D(R)\) satisfies \(\mathrm{ARO}_\alpha\) if and only if \(\text{pgd}_\alpha(R)\leq 2\). 

\end{itemize}} The paper gives a significant list of examples and counterexamples deduced from it.

After that, it looks (Section 4) at some triangulated categories coming from topology (as \(\mathcal Sp\), but also its motivic analogue) or algebraic geometry (derived categories of sheaves, of projectives or injective modules), showing that, \textit{under the continuum hypothesis}, a lot of them satisfies \(\mathrm{ARO}_{\aleph_1}\).

In Section 5, the authors discuss the still open conjecture of Neeman on \textit{Rosick√Ω functors} -- see [\textit{A. Neeman}, J. Topol. 2, No. 2, 262--276 (2009; Zbl 1179.18005)].

title.title: Enhanced $A$-infinity obstruction theory

editorial_contributions.text:
Let \(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal E}\) be the triangulated derivator associated to an exact category \(\mathcal{E}\). \textit{G. Maltsiniotis} [``La \(K\)-th√©orie d'un d√©rivateur triangul√©'', Contemp. Math. 431, 341--373 (2007; Zbl 1136.18002)] defined a \(K\)-theory of \(\mathbb{D}\mathcal{E}\) together with natural homomorphisms \(\rho_n : K_n({\mathcal E}) \to K_n(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal E})\) \((n \geq 0)\) and conjectured that all these \(\rho_n\) are isomorphisms. Really, Maltsiniotis succeeds in proving the conjecture for \(n=0\) there. The aim of this paper is to prove that \(\rho_1\) is an isomorphism (Theorem 1). 

Let \(C^b({\mathcal E})\) denote the Waldhausen category of bounded complexes in \({\mathcal E}\), with quasi-isomorphisms as weak equivalences and cofibrations given by chain morphisms which are levelwise admissible monomorphisms. There is a theorem, called the Gillet-Waldhausen theorem, which relates Quillen's \(K\)-theory to Waldhausen's \(K\)-theory. This states that the homomorphism \(\tau_1 : K_1({\mathcal E}) \to K_1(C^b({\mathcal E}))\) induced by the inclusion \({\mathcal E} \subset C^b({\mathcal E})\) of complexes concentrated in degree 0 is an isomorphism. Set \({\mathcal W}=C^b({\mathcal E})\) and let \(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal W}\) denote the right pointed derivator associated to \({\mathcal W}\). Then according to the paper of \textit{G. Garkusha} [St. Petersbg. Math. J. 18, No.~6, 957--996 (2007); translation from Algebra Anal. 18, No.~6, 131--186 (2006; Zbl 1136.19001)], one has the group \(K_1(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal W})\) and the comparison homomorphism \(\mu_1 : K_1({\mathcal W}) \to K_1(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal W})\), and then one finds that \(\mathbb{D}C^b({\mathcal E})=\mathbb{D}{\mathcal E}\) and \(\rho_1\) factors as 

\[
\rho_1 : K_1({\mathcal E}) \overset{\tau_1}{\longrightarrow} K_1(C^b({\mathcal E})) \overset{\mu_1}{\longrightarrow} K_1(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal E}).
\]
 
So the aim of this paper above can be rephrased as proving that \(\mu_1\) is an isomorphism (Theorem 2). The proof of this result uses techniques introduced by the author and \textit{A. Tonks} [Adv. Math. 216, No.~1, 178--211 (2007; Zbl 1125.19001)]. There they define a stable quadratic module \({\mathcal D}^{\text{der}}_*{\mathcal W}\) for \({\mathcal W}\) which models the 1-type of the Waldhausen \(K\)-theory spectrum \(K({\mathcal W})\). Here the author constructs an analogous module \({\mathcal D}_*^{\text{der}}{\mathcal W}\) which models the 1-type of the derived \(K\)-theory spectrum \(DK({\mathcal W})\) (this has already been known to be weakly equivalent to \(K(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal W}\)) [\textit{G. Garkusha}, Math. Z. 249, No.~3, 641--682 (2005; Zbl 1074.19001)]), and proves that there is a natural isomorphism \(\bar{\mu} : {\mathcal D}_*{\mathcal W} \to {\mathcal D}_*^{\text{der}}{\mathcal W}\) of stable quadratic modules (Theorem 6.1).

From this it follows that \(\mu_1\) is an isomorphism and hence the main result can be obtained. (In fact, more generally for a Waldhausen category \({\mathcal W}\) with cylinders and a saturated class of weak equivalences, it is proved that there are natural isomorphisms \(\mu_n : K_n({\mathcal W}) \to K_n(\mathbb{D}{\mathcal W})\) for \(n=0, 1\).)

title.title: Maltsiniotis's first conjecture for \(K_{1}\)

editorial_contributions.text: Over a field, minimal models for operadic algebras go back to Kadeishvili's theorem [\textit{T. V. Kadeishvili}, Tr. Tbilis. Mat. Inst. Razmadze 91, 19--27 (1988; Zbl 0717.55011)]]. He showed that the homology graded algebra \(H_\ast(A)\) of a differential graded associative algebra \(A\) carries an essentially unique \(A_\infty\)-algebra structure, consisting of degree \(r-2\) maps, \(r \ge 3\), \(m_r : H_\ast(A)^{\otimes^r}\to H_\ast(A)\) satisfying certain equations, which is \(\infty\)-quasi-isomorphic to \(A\). Over a commutative ring \(R\), \textit{S. Sagave} [J. Reine Angew. Math. 639, 73--105 (2010; Zbl 1209.18011)] had the clever idea of replacing complexes with \(R\)-projective bicomplexes whose vertical homology is also \(R\)-projective. \par In this paper the authors develop a theory of minimal models extending Sagave's results to algebras \(A\) over a Koszul operad \(\mathcal{O}\) (in the sense of [\textit{B. Fresse}, Contemp. Math. 346, 115--215 (2004; Zbl 1077.18007)]) with trivial differential such that \(\mathcal{O}\) is non-symmetric or the field of rationals \(\mathbb{Q} \subseteq R\). Constructed minimal models are bigraded and contain a projective resolution of the homology.

msc.text: Algebraic operads, cooperads, and Koszul duality
Fundamental constructions in algebraic geometry involving higher and derived categories (homotopical algebraic geometry, derived algebraic geometry, etc.)
Syzygies, resolutions, complexes in associative algebras
Abstract and axiomatic homotopy theory in algebraic topology

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: In this paper a relation between iterated cyclings and iterated powers of elements in a Garside group is shown. This yields a characterization of elements in a Garside group having a rigid power, where `rigid' means that the left normal form changes only in the obvious way under cycling and decycling. It is also shown that, given \(X\) in a Garside group, if some power \(X^m\) is conjugate to a rigid element, then \(m\) can be bounded above by \(\|\Delta\|^3\). In the particular case of braid groups \(\{B_n;\;n\in\mathbb{N}\}\), this implies that a pseudo-Anosov braid has a small power whose ultra summit set consists of rigid elements. This solves one of the problems in the way of a polynomial solution to the conjugacy decision problem (CDP) and the conjugacy search problem (CSP) in braid groups. In addition to proving the rigidity theorem, it will be shown how this paper fits into the authors' program for finding a polynomial algorithm to the CDP/CSP, and what remains to be done.

msc.text: Word problems, other decision problems, connections with logic and automata (group-theoretic aspects)
Generators, relations, and presentations of groups

title.title: Conjugacy in Garside groups. III: Periodic braids.

editorial_contributions.text:
Summary: This paper is the second in a series in which the authors study the conjugacy decision problem (CDP) and the conjugacy search problem (CSP) in Garside groups.

 The ultra summit set \(\text{USS}(X)\) of an element \(X\) in a Garside group \(G\) is a finite set of elements in \(G\), which is a complete invariant of the conjugacy class of \(X\) in \(G\). A fundamental question, if one wishes to find bounds on the size of \(\text{USS}(X)\), is to understand its structure. In this paper we introduce two new operations on elements \(Y\in\text{USS}(X)\), called `partial cycling' and `partial twisted decycling', and prove that if \(Y,Z\in\text{USS}(X)\), then \(Y\) and \(Z\) are related by sequences of partial cyclings and partial twisted decyclings. These operations are a concrete way to understand the minimal simple elements whose existence follows from the convexity property of ultra summit sets.

 Using partial cycling and partial twisted decycling, we investigate the structure of a directed graph \(\Gamma_X\) determined by \(\text{USS}(X)\), and show that \(\Gamma_X\) can be decomposed into `black' and `grey' subgraphs. There are applications relating to the authors' program for finding a polynomial solution to the CDP/CSP in the case of braids, which is outlined in the first paper of this series [ibid. 1, No. 3, 221-279 (2007; Zbl 1160.20026)]. A different application is to give a new algorithm for solving the CDP/CSP in Garside groups which is faster than all other known algorithms, even though its theoretical complexity is the same as that of the established algorithm using ultra summit sets. There are also applications to the theory of reductive groups.

msc.text: Word problems, other decision problems, connections with logic and automata (group-theoretic aspects)
Generators, relations, and presentations of groups

title.title: Conjugacy in Garside groups. II: Structure of the ultra summit set.

editorial_contributions.text: The author proves a conjecture due to Makanin: if \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are elements of the Artin braid group \(B_n\) such that \(\alpha^k=\beta^k\) for some nonzero integer \(k\), then \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) are conjugate. The proof involves the Nielsen-Thurston classification of braids.

title.title: The \(n\)th root of a braid is unique up to conjugacy.

editorial_contributions.text: The authors present a new algorithm to solve the conjugacy problem in Artin braid groups, which is faster than the one presented by \textit{J. Birman}, \textit{K. H. Ko} and \textit{S. J. Lee} [Adv. Math. 139, No. 2, 322-353 (1998; Zbl 0937.20016)]. This algorithm can be applied not only to braid groups, but to all Garside groups (which include finite type Artin groups and torus knot groups, among others).

title.title: Conjugacy problem for braid groups and Garside groups.

editorial_contributions.text:
The authors consider braid groups of closed orientable surfaces of positive genus. They construct a universal, faithful Vassiliev invariant with integer coefficients for braids on surfaces. It takes values in the completion of the graded algebra of extended chord diagrams of the surface, which they construct as follows. First, they define the algebra of horizontal \(n\)-string chords of the surface; this is a version of the corresponding algebra from the Vassiliev theory of classical pure braids, with chords labeled by elements of the fundamental group of the surface, \(G\). They go on noting that both \(\Sigma_n\) and \(G^n\) naturally act on the above algebra; this gives rise to an algebra of extended chord diagrams, \(E_n\). Using Magnus expansion, they construct an additive map from the group ring of \(n\)-braids to \(E_n\). They prove that this map sends the Vassiliev filtration of braids into the natural filtration of \(E_n\) and induces a multiplicative isomorphism between the associated graded objects, which are moreover torsion-free.

The above results naturally extend those proved by the reviewer [Topology Appl. 118, 169--185 (2002; Zbl 0987.57002)], for classical Artin braids. The presence of the fundamental group \(G\) makes things considerably more difficult, in the case of closed surfaces.

When following the method of proof from the classical case, one has to check a key almost-direct product property. For Artin braids, this is well-known: It means that, by forgetting one string, one gets a surjection with free kernel between the pure braid groups, \(P_n\twoheadrightarrow P_{n-1}\), which has a section and trivial monodromy on homology.

In the paper under review, the authors replace \(P_n\) by the kernel of the natural map from the pure braid group of the surface to \(G^n\), \(K_n\). In this way, they obtain an induced surjection, \(K_n\twoheadrightarrow K_{n-1}\), with free kernel. To get the section, they use the doubling operation on pure braids of punctured surfaces. To check the monodromy condition, they make a careful analysis of conjugation in \(K_n\). They also obtain a description of the associated graded Lie algebra of \(K_n\), and a proof of its torsion-freeness (as a graded Abelian group).

series.title: Transactions of the American Mathematical Society

title.title: Vassiliev invariants for braids on surfaces

editorial_contributions.text: For any given element of the \(n\)-string braid group, a small generating set of its centralizer is computed. This leads to sharp bounds for the size of a generating set for the centalizer, which is described in terms of semidirect and direct products of mixed braid groups. Nice figures and examples accompany the theorems. An explicit construction for the generating set is given.

msc.text: Generators, relations, and presentations of groups

title.title: zbMATH Open Web Interface contents unavailable due to conflicting licenses.

editorial_contributions.text: The following main results are obtained: 1) If \(M\) is a closed orientable surface, then the pure braid group \(PB_n(M)\) is orderable (Theorem 1.6); 2) If \(M\) is a closed, non-orientable surface, then the pure braid group \(PB_n(M)\) has generalized torsion, for \(n\geq 2\). Therefore, \(PB_n(M)\) is not orderable for \(n\geq 2\) (Theorem 1.7).

title.title: Solving the conjugacy problem in Garside groups by cyclic sliding.

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: In this paper we give new presentations of the braid groups and the pure braid groups of a closed surface. We also give an algorithm to solve the word problem in these groups, using the given presentations.

title.title: Reducible braids and Garside theory.

editorial_contributions.text:
Given any braid \(x\in B_n\), the set of sliding circuits \(SC(x)\) has been used by \textit{V. Gebhardt} and \textit{J. Gonz√°lez-Meneses}, [J. Symb. Comput. 45, No. 6, 629-656 (2010; Zbl 1235.20032)], in order to simplify the solution of the conjugacy problem in \(B_n\). \(SC(x)\) consists of all conjugates \(y\) of \(x\) that belong to a sliding circuit, meaning that \(y\) coincides with the cyclic sliding \(\mathfrak s^m(y)\) for some \(m>0\). The cyclic sliding \(\mathfrak s(y)\) is defined as the conjugate \(\mathfrak p(y)^{-1}y\mathfrak p(y)\), where \(\mathfrak p(y)\) is the preferred prefix of \(y\) [\textit{V. Gebhardt} and \textit{J. Gonz√°lez-Meneses}, Math. Z. 265, No. 1, 85-114 (2010; Zbl 1253.20034)].

 The paper under review is aimed to provide a family of braids \(\beta\) whose number of sliding circuits is exponential in both the number of strands and the canonical length. Namely, for \(n\geq 3\) and \(k\geq 1\) the braid \(\beta=(\sigma_1\cdots\sigma_{n-1})^{nk+1}\sigma_{n+1}^{4k+1}\in B_{n+2}\) of canonical length \(\ell(\beta)=4k+1\) is proved to have \(\#(SC(\beta))\geq 2^{n-2}(n-1)^{2k-1}\).

 This result is proved by considering the decomposition of braids along standard canonical reduction systems, that is invariant sets of disjoint essential round circles.

For the entire collection see [Zbl 1210.14004].

title.title: On reduction curves and Garside properties of braids.

editorial_contributions.text:
In the present work, the authors show another view of Khovanov cohomology different from the \(n\)-cube procedure but not far from it. The \(n\)-cube procedure has been used before in work of \textit{D. Bar-Natan} [Algebr. Geom. Topol. 2, 337--370 (2002; Zbl 0998.57016)] and many others to compute the Jones polynomial and Khovanov cohomology. The idea of smoothings and parameters are in some way identical.

The authors prove that the potential extreme Khovanov cohomology of a link is the cohomology of the independence simplicial complex of its Lando graph. They also provide a family of knots having as many non-trivial extreme Khovanov cohomology modules as desired, that is, examples of \(H\)-thick knots that are as far from being \(H\)-thin as desired.

The paper starts by a review of the well-known theory given by \textit{M. Khovanov} [Duke Math. J. 101, No. 3, 359--426 (2000; Zbl 0960.57005)] in the end of the last century and how it was developed by Bar Natan by using the \(n\)-cube concept. \textit{O. Viro} in [Fundam. Math. 184, 317--342 (2004; Zbl 1078.57013)] introduced a nice and important view of Khovanov cohomology by using Kauffman's techniques of enhanced states which in my opinion is another missing part of the Khovanov story for link homology. The authors present an overview of the history and ideas of enhanced states and then pass over to the Lando graph of a link diagram that they will use later according to the relations to the Jones polynomial and hence Khovanov cohomology. This fact comes from the independence number. The Jones polynomial can be shown to be the Euler characteristic of Khovanov cohomology and the independence also suggests the formula of Euler characteristic. Here the authors understand that both ideas led to the study extremely Khovanov cohomology in term of this graph.

In Section 2 they present Khovanov cohomology in terms of enhanced states as a first step to their goal, cf. Viro's work [loc. cit.]. In this section they introduce the Lando graph and its cohomology in more details.

In Section 3 the authors refer to the corresponding cochain complex as the Lando cochain complex, and to the corresponding cohomology modules as the Lando cohomology. They also note that the independence number of the Lando graph is the Euler characteristic associated with the Lando cohomology. Theorem 3.2 in [\textit{Y. Bae} and \textit{H. R. Morton}, J. Knot Theory Ramifications 12, No. 3, 359--373 (2003; Zbl 1064.57010)] is given with Theorem 3.3 in [\textit{P. M. G. Manch√≥n},  ibid. 13, No. 2, 277--295 (2004; Zbl 1065.57010)] to find a connection between both enhanced states and the Jones polynomial. Again the authors find two paths for the Jones polynomial as a bigraded Euler characteristic for Khovanov cohomology. On the other hand, the formula for the independence number suggests that each extreme coefficient of the Jones polynomial is the Euler characteristic of a certain homology given in terms of independence vertices of the Lando graph. Both ideas together have led them to a way of understanding the extreme Khovanov cohomology in terms of this graph; in other words, they have obtained a geometric realization of the potential extreme Khovanov cohomology of a link.

Section 4 is on the Lando graph and extreme Khovanov cohomology which is the heart of the work. This section puts a ground to the work of Section 5. The authors prove that the Lando cochain complex is a copy of the potential extreme Khovanov complex, with the degrees shifted by a constant (Theorem 4.4). In this section there is also an example showing how to apply this theorem in order to compute extreme Khovanov cohomology in a practical way. The rest of the paper deals with applications of Theorem 4.4.

In Section 5 the authors construct a simplicial complex whose homology is equal to the cohomology of the Lando ascendant complex of the link diagram \(D\) up to homological shift. Theorem 4.4 implies that the homology of the simplicial complex determines the extreme Khovanov cohomology of the link represented by \(D\). As Lando graphs are bipartite, Theorems 5.1 and 5.2, together with the fact that a simplicial complex \(X\) and its suspension \(S(X)\) have the same homology and cohomology up to a homological shift by 1, provide an algorithm for computing the cohomology of the independence simplicial complex associated with a Lando graph \(G_D\) (or, equivalently, the extreme Khovanov cohomology of the link represented by \(D\)) from the homology of a specific simplicial complex). In addition to Remark 5.4 which is very interesting, the following theorems give a good idea of the results and applications. I really enjoyed this work.

Section 6 is devoted to families of \(H\)-thick knots. The section starts with the fact that there are 249 prime unoriented knots with at most 10 crossings (not counting mirror images). It is known that all but 12 of these knots are \(H\)-thin, that is, their Khovanov cohomology is supported on two adjacent diagonals, in a matrix in which rows are indexed by \(j\) and columns by \(i\). An \(H\)-thick knot is a knot that is not \(H\)-thin. For example, any non-split alternating link is \(H\)-thin, and any adequate non-alternating knot is \(H\)-thick. After some introduction the authors arrive at the following question: Does any oriented link \(L\) have a diagram \(D\) whose associated \(j_{\mathrm{min}}(D)\) equals the minimum value of \(j\) such that \(H_{i,j}(L)\) is non-trivial for at least one value of \(i\)?

The authors show examples of \(H\)-thick knots having any arbitrary number of non-trivial cohomology groups in the non-trivial row of smallest possible index. More precisely, they provide a diagram \(D\) whose row indexed by \(j_{\mathrm{min}}(D)\) is non-trivial, and hence corresponds to the non-trivial row of smallest possible index. Moreover, this row has as many non-trivial cohomology groups as desired. The authors also remark that Theorem 4.4 allows them to compute the extreme Khovanov cohomology of any link diagram \(D\) by considering independently each of the circles appearing in \(s_AD\), since the non-admissible  \(A\)-chords do not take part in the construction of the simplicial complex \(Y_D\) described in Section 5.

title.title: A geometric description of the extreme Khovanov cohomology

editorial_contributions.text: The authors give a new method to compute the centralizer of an element in Artin braid groups and, more generally, in Garside groups. This method, together with the solution of the conjugacy problem given previously by the authors, are two main steps for solving conjugacy systems, thus breaking recently discovered cryptosystems based in braid groups. They also present the result of their computations, where they notice that their algorithm yields surprisingly small generating sets for the centralizers.

editorial_contributions.text:
Summary: There are recent cryptographic protocols that are based on Multiple Simultaneous Conjugacy Problems in braid groups. We improve an algorithm, due to Sang Jin Lee and Eonkyung Lee, to solve these problems, by applying a method developed by the author and Nuno Franco, originally intended to solve the Conjugacy Search Problem in braid groups.

For the entire collection see [Zbl 1063.20001].

title.title: Parabolic subgroups of complex braid groups

editorial_contributions.text:
A Garside monoid is a cancellative monoid where greatest common divisors and least common multiples exist and some finiteness conditions are satisfied.

The authors propose a new procedure to determine the growth function of a homogeneous Garside monoid, with respect to the finite generating set formed by the atoms. They present a formula for the growth function of each Artin-Tits monoid of spherical type (hence of each braid monoid) with respect to the standard generators, as the inverse of the determinant of a very simple matrix. They show that the exponential growth rates of the Artin-Tits monoids of type \(A_n\) (positive braid monoids) tend to \(3.233636\ldots\) as \(n\) tends to infinity. This number is well-known, as it is the growth rate of the coefficients of the only formal power series \(x_0(y) =-(1+ y+2y^2+4y^3+9y^4+\cdots )\) which is the leading root of the classical partial theta function \(\sum _{k=0}^{\infty}y^{\binom{k}{2}}x^k\). They also describe the sequence 1, 1, 2, 4, 9, \(\ldots\) formed by the coefficients of \(-x_0(y)\), by showing that its \(k\)th term (the coefficient of \(y_k\)) is equal to the number of braids of length \(k\), in the positive braid monoid \(A_{\infty}\) on an infinite number of strands, whose maximal lexicographic representative starts with the first generator \(a_1\). This is an unexpected connection between the partial theta function and the theory of braids.

msc.text: Theta series; Weil representation; theta correspondences

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: These are Lecture Notes of a course given by the author at the School Winter Braids, held at the Universit√© de Pau et des Pays de L'Adour (France), on February 2015. It is explained how mapping class groups, and in particular braid groups, act on some interesting geometric spaces like the hyperbolic plane and the complex of curves, and how this allows to obtain some algebraic properties of the groups. A proof of the hyperbolicity of the graph of curves, following Hensel-Przytycki-Webb, is given.

Hyperbolic groups and nonpositively curved groups

title.title: Polynomial braid combing

editorial_contributions.text:
The paper under review studies the relation of simple braids and the so called Morton-Franks-Williams inequality. If \( T(\alpha)\) is a simple braid having permutation \(\alpha\) and \(\hat T(\alpha)\) denotes the closure of the braid \( T(\alpha)\), then the authors show:

Proposition 2.1. Let \(\alpha\in S_n\) be a permutation with length \(w=\ell(\alpha)\). Then \(\partial_v^{+}(P(\hat T_{\alpha}))=w+n-1\) if and only if \(\alpha=id\), and the coefficient of \(v^{w+n-1}\) in \(P(\hat T_{id})\) is \((-z)^{1-n}\).

This is the main result of the paper, which appears in Section 2, and in the remaining three sections the authors use the result above to obtain several applications. In Section 3 they reprove the following result:

Theorem 3.1 (K√°lm√°n):

 The set of simple braids \(\{T_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S_n}\) is an orthonormal basis for \(< .\;,\;. >_R\).

In Section 4 the authors consider the concept of simple resolution tree and the main result is to say when the closure of a braid satisfies the Morton-Franks-Williams inequality in terms of its simple resolution tree. Namely:

Theorem 4.1: Let \(L=\hat b\) be a link obtained as the closure of a positive braid \(b\) of \(n\) strands and writhe \(w\). Then \(b\) admits a simple resolution tree and, moreover, the Morton-Franks-Williams upper bound is sharp for \(L\), that is, \(\partial_v^+(P(L))=w+n-1\), if and only if at least one leaf in this simple resolution tree is the identity braid.

Then several results in form of corollaries are derived. In Section 5 the authors study the braid index of the closure of positive braids on 3 strands. The main result is Theorem 5.1 where they describe, up to cyclic permutation, for which positive words the closure of the corresponding braid have braid index less than three. More precisely they show that this is the case if and only if the positive word \(w\) is one of the words: {\parindent=6mm\begin{itemize}\item[1-] \(\sigma_1\sigma_2^p \;or \;\sigma_2\sigma_1^p,\text{ for }p\geq 0,\) \item[2-] \(\sigma_1\sigma_2 \sigma_1^p\sigma_2^q \text{ or } \sigma_2\sigma_1 \sigma_2^p\sigma_1^q. \) 

\end{itemize}}

title.title: Closures of positive braids and the Morton-Franks-Williams inequality

editorial_contributions.text: zbMATH Open Web Interface contents unavailable due to conflicting licenses.

title.title: The root extraction problem for generic braids

editorial_contributions.text:
For a crossing in a link diagram \(D\) we can define two types of `smoothing'; \(A\)-smoothing and \(B\)-smoothing, which were used by \textit{L. H.~Kauffman} to define the Jones polynomial [Topology 26, 395--407 (1987; Zbl 0622.57004)]. Let \(s_A(D)\) (\(s_B(D)\), respectively) be the circles that appear when one changes each crossing by \(A\)-smoothing (\(B\)-smoothing, respectively), and let \(|s_A(D)|\) (\(|s_B(D)|\), respectively) be the number of circles in \(s_A(D)\) (\(s_B(D)\), respectively). One can make an alternating diagram by changing several crossings if necessary. If the least number of such crossings, which are called dealternators, is \(k\), the diagram is called \(k\)-almost alternating. Let \(D_i\) be the diagram obtained from a \(k\)-almost alternating diagram \(D\) by smoothing all the dealternators in some way (\(i=1,2,\dots,2^k\)). The diagram \(D\) is called dealternator connected (dealternator reduced, respectively) if \(D_i\) is connected (reduced, respectively) for any \(i\), cf. \textit{C. C. Adams} et al. [Topology Appl. 46, No.~2, 151--165 (1992; Zbl 0766.57003)]. 

The authors construct a surface of genus \(k\) with \(k\) boundary components from a \(k\)-almost alternating diagram \(D\), and prove a formula for \(|s_A(D)+|s_B(D)|\). In particular, if the diagram is dealternator connected and has \(n\) crossings, the equality \(|s_A(D)|+|s_B(D)|=n+2-2k\) follows. As a corollary the authors obtain an upper bound of the span of the Jones polynomial by \textit{J.~Zhou} [J. Knot Theory Ramifications 6, No.~1, 125--148 (1997; Zbl 0878.57014)].

They also show a similar result for the case where a diagram is dealternator connected and dealternator reduced and a relation to the Turaev genus (the genus of a surface appearing as a cobordism from \(s_A(D)\) and \(s_B(D)\)) of a dealternator connected diagram, \textit{O. T. Dasbach}, et al. [J. Comb. Theory, Ser. B 98, No.~2, 384--399 (2008; Zbl 1135.05015)], \textit{V. G. Turaev} [Enseign. Math., II. Ser. 33, 203--225 (1987; Zbl 0668.57009)]).

references.text: Adams C. C., An Elementary Introduction to the Mathematical Theory of Knots, in: The Knot Book (1994)
Turaev V. G., L'Enseignement Math. 33 pp 203--

title.title: On the centralizer of generic braids

editorial_contributions.text: The authors extend a result of \textit{R. Fenn}, \textit{E. Keyman}, and \textit{C. Rourke} [J. Knot Theory Ramifications 7, No. 7, 881-892 (1998; Zbl 0971.57011)] -- that the singular braid monoid of a disc embeds in a group -- to the case of the singular braid monoid of an orientable surface. As in the original result, the group in question, the singular braid group, arises from the singular braid monoid by allowing a pair of consecutive singularities along two strands to cancel.

msc.text: Other groups related to topology or analysis
Free semigroups, generators and relations, word problems

title.title: On the singular braid monoid of an orientable surface.

editorial_contributions.text: zbMATH Open Web Interface contents unavailable due to conflicting licenses.

title.title: Ordering pure braid groups on closed surfaces

editorial_contributions.text:
Let \(G\) be a group, \(S\) be a Sylow \(p\)-subgroup of \(G\) and \(1
eq A\) be a strongly closed subgroup of \(S\), i.e., if \(1
eq a\in A\), \(g\in G\) with \(a^g\in S\), then \(a^g\in A\). In [Ann. Math. (2) 99, 70-117 (1974; Zbl 0276.20011)] 	extit{D. M. Goldschmidt} classified all such groups \(G=\langle A^Gangle\) provided \(p=2\) and \(A\) is elementary Abelian. This was one of the crucial tools in the classification of the finite simple groups.

 In this paper the authors extend this result to arbitrary primes \(p\) and even to non-Abelian groups \(A\), for \(G=\langle A^Gangle\). As any Sylow \(p\)-subgroup is strongly closed in itself they have to assume that \(A
eq S\). Generic examples are finite simple groups of Lie type in characteristic \(r
eq p\), such that \(S\) is Abelian but not elementary Abelian. For the proof the authors reduce the problem to \(G\) being simple. Then they use the classification of the finite simple groups and check if such a group satisfies the assumption. In contrast to this paper the proof due to Goldschmidt does not use the classification of the finite simple groups.

keywords: finite simple groups of Lie type

msc.text: Finite simple groups and their classification

editorial_contributions.text:
This work is concerned with the notion of cellular space introduced by \textit{E. Dror Farjoun} [Cellular spaces, null spaces and homotopy localization. Berlin: Springer-Verlag (1995; Zbl 0842.55001)]. A class of pointed spaces closed both under weak equivalences and homotopy colimits is called cellular and the smallest cellular class containing a given pointed space \(A\) is denoted \(\mathcal{C}(A)\). The relation \(X\in{\mathcal C}(A)\) is written \(X \gg A\).

With this notion, the authors change the perspective between a nilpotent space \(X\) and its Postnikov tower \(P_n X\). It is usual to consider \(X\) as homotopy limit of \(P_n X\) but here the authors prove that the Postnikov sections can be constructed out of \(X\) by means of wedges, homotopy pushouts and telescopes. In the previous setting that means \(P_nX\gg X\) if \(P_n X\) is nilpotent.

This theorem is established by using a modified Bousfield-Kan completion tower \(\ldots\to z_kX\to\ldots\to z_0X\), already defined by \textit{E. Dror Farjoun} [Contemp. Math. 265, 27--39 (2000; Zbl 0971.55017)], and the property \(z_k X\gg X\).

The authors present also some consequences of this main result. First, mention the following extension of the ``key lemma'' of \textit{A. K. Bousfield} [Am. J. Math. 119, No. 6, 1321--1354 (1997; Zbl 0886.55011)]: let \(X\) be a connected space whose fundamental group \(\pi_1 X\) is nilpotent. If the map \(\pi_1: {\mathrm{map}}_*(X,X)\to {\mathrm{Hom}}(\pi_1X,\pi_1X)\) is a weak equivalence, then \(X\) is weakly equivalent to \(K(\pi_1X,1)\). They provide also an extension of the classical Serre class statements. In particular, for any reduced homology theory \(\mathcal K\), if \(X\) is nilpotent, they prove that \(\prod_{k\geq 1} K(\pi_kX,k)\) is \(\mathcal K\)-acyclic if and only if \(\prod_{k\geq 1} K(H_k(X;\mathbb Z),k)\) is \(\mathcal K\)-acyclic.

title.title: Cellular properties of nilpotent spaces

editorial_contributions.text:
The authors obtain an explicit proof of the Baum-Connes conjecture for the lamplighter groups of finite groups. More precisely, for a finite group \(F\), one may consider the wreath product \(L:= F\wr \mathbb Z\), which is usually called a lamplighter group (the original lamplighter group arises by taking \(F=\mathbb Z_2\), where \(\mathbb Z_2\) is the group of two elements). The Baum-Connes conjecture for a discrete group \(G\) states that the assembly map 
\[
\mu_i^G : K_i^G(\underline{E}G) \rightarrow K_i(C^*_r(G))
\]
 is an isomorphism for \(i=0,1\). Here, the left-hand side is the \(G\)-equivariant \(K\)-homology of the classifying space \(\underline{E}G\) for proper actions of \(G\), and the right-hand side is the topological \(K\)-theory of the reduced \(C^*\)-algebra of \(G\). The Baum-Connes conjecture is already known to hold for \(L\), since \(L\) is an amenable group, but the authors obtain an explicit description of all the elements in the formula. Explicitly, for \(i=0\), the assembly map \(\mu^L_0\) is an isomorphism between two free abelian groups of countably infinite rank, and for \(i=1\), the assembly map \(\mu^L_1\) is an isomorphism between two infinite cyclic groups.

In addition, the authors also study the isomorphism problem for the \(C^*\)-algebras of the different lamplighter groups \(L= F\wr \mathbb Z\). They show that, for \(F\) a finite abelian group, the group \(C^*\)-algebra \(C^*(L)=C^*_r(L)\) is completely determined within the above class by the order of \(F\). They also show that the stable rank of the \(C^*(L)\) is \(2\) for the lamplighter group of any non-trivial finite group \(F\).

title.title: \(K\)-homology and \(K\)-theory for the lamplighter groups of finite groups

editorial_contributions.text: Let \(A\) be a pointed connected space. A space \(X\) is called \(A\)-null if the natural inclusion \(A\hookrightarrow\) map \((A,X)\) is a weak equivalence. The \(A\)-nullification \({\mathbf P}_AX\) is the only \(A\)-null space, up to homotopical equivalence, endowed with a map \(X\to{\mathbf P}_AX\) which induces, for every \(A\)-null space \(Y\), a weak homotopy equivalence, map\(({\mathbf P}_AX,Y)@>\simeq>>\) map\((X,Y)\). A space \(X\) is \(A\)-cellular if for any choice of base point in \(X\) and for every pointed map \(f:Y\to Z\) such that \(f_A:\text{map}_*(A,Y)\to\text{map}_*(A,Z)\) is a weak equivalence we have that \(f_X:\text{map}_*(X,Y) \to\text{map}_*(X,Z)\) is also a weak equivalence. In this paper \(A=B \mathbb{Z}/p\) and \(X=BG\) with \(p\) a prime number and \(G\) a finite group. The first result characterizes \({\mathbf P}_AX\) as the total space of a covering fibration over the classifying space of some quotient of \(G\). The second result provides us with a characterization of the class of finite groups \(G\) such that \(X\) is \(A\)-cellular. The author also studies carefully the relationship between \(A\)-homotopy theory of \(X\) \((A\) playing the r√¥le of \(S^0)\) and the algebraic properties of the group \(G\).

editorial_contributions.text: Dror Farjoun suggested that the mod \(p\) homotopy of the classifying space of a finite group may be understood by studying its \(B{\mathbb Z}/p\)-cellularization. This approach was used by the first author in [Trans. Am. Math. Soc. 359, No.~4, 1791--1816 (2007; Zbl 1112.55009)] and the paper under review develops this work. It is shown that this cellularization usually has infinitely many non-trivial homotopy groups, and results are given concerning \(p\)-torsion in these groups.

Homotopy groups, general; sets of homotopy classes

editorial_contributions.text:
Elementary amenable groups are defined as the smallest class of groups that contains all finite groups and is closed under extensions and direct unions. \textit{J. A. Hillman} defined, [in J. Aust. Math. Soc., Ser. A 50, No. 1, 160-170 (1991; Zbl 0733.57009)], the notion of Hirsch length for elementary amenable groups.

 The authors prove the following Theorem 1. Let \(G\) be an elementary amenable group of finite Hirsch length. Then the Hirsch length equals the Bredon homological dimension of \(G\). -- A corollary of their results is that if \(G\) is a countable elementary amenable group of finite Hirsch length \(hG\) and if the Bredon cohomological dimension of \(G\) is not 2, then \(G\) admits a model for the universal space for proper actions which is of dimension less than or equal to \(hG+1\). The authors also prove that if \(G\) is of Bredon type \(FP_\infty\) then the Bredon cohomological and homological dimension of \(G\) coincide.

series.title: Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society

title.title: On Bredon homology of elementary amenable groups.

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We define new families of Tillich-Z\'emor hash functions, using higher dimensional special linear groups over finite fields as platforms. The Cayley graphs of these groups combine fast mixing properties and high girth, which together give rise to good preimage and collision resistance of the corresponding hash functions. We justify the claim that the resulting hash functions are post-quantum secure.

title.title: Post-quantum hash functions using $\mathrm{SL}_n(\mathbb{F}_p)$

editorial_contributions.text:
A Garside monoid is a cancellative monoid where greatest common divisors and least common multiples exist and some finiteness conditions are satisfied.

The authors propose a new procedure to determine the growth function of a homogeneous Garside monoid, with respect to the finite generating set formed by the atoms. They present a formula for the growth function of each Artin-Tits monoid of spherical type (hence of each braid monoid) with respect to the standard generators, as the inverse of the determinant of a very simple matrix. They show that the exponential growth rates of the Artin-Tits monoids of type \(A_n\) (positive braid monoids) tend to \(3.233636\ldots\) as \(n\) tends to infinity. This number is well-known, as it is the growth rate of the coefficients of the only formal power series \(x_0(y) =-(1+ y+2y^2+4y^3+9y^4+\cdots )\) which is the leading root of the classical partial theta function \(\sum _{k=0}^{\infty}y^{\binom{k}{2}}x^k\). They also describe the sequence 1, 1, 2, 4, 9, \(\ldots\) formed by the coefficients of \(-x_0(y)\), by showing that its \(k\)th term (the coefficient of \(y_k\)) is equal to the number of braids of length \(k\), in the positive braid monoid \(A_{\infty}\) on an infinite number of strands, whose maximal lexicographic representative starts with the first generator \(a_1\). This is an unexpected connection between the partial theta function and the theory of braids.

source.source: J. Comb. Theory, Ser. A 190, Article ID 105623, 39 p. (2022).

title.title: On the growth of Artin-Tits monoids and the partial theta function

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: In this paper, Lusternik-Schinrelmann and geometric category of finite spaces are considered. We define new numerical invariants of these spaces derived from the geometric category and present an algorithmic approach for its effective computation. The analysis is undertaken by combining homotopic features of the spaces, algorithms and tools from the theory of graphs and hypergraphs. We also provide a number of examples.

editorial_contributions.text:
Let \(n \geq 0\) be an integer and let \(A_{n}\) denotes the Artin group of dihedral type, which is the group defined by \(A_{n} = <a, b \mid \mathrm{prod}(a, b; n)= \mathrm{prod}(b,a;n)>\), here \(\mathrm{prod}(x,y;n)\) denotes the word of length \(n\) that alternates \(x\) and \(y\) and starts with \(x\).

In this paper, the authors compute the Bredon homology groups (see [\textit{G. E. Bredon}, Equivariant cohomology theories. Berlin-Heidelberg-New York: Springer-Verlag (1967; Zbl 0162.27202); \textit{G. Mislin} and \textit{A. Valette}, Proper group actions and the Baum-Connes conjecture. Basel: Birkh√§user (2003; Zbl 1028.46001)]) of the classifying space of \(A_{n}\) for the family of virtually cyclic groups, with coefficients in the \(K\)-theory of a group ring.

The authors describe the relations of their work with the Farrell-Jones conjecture (see [\textit{F. T. Farrell} and \textit{L. E. Jones}, J. Am. Math. Soc. 6, No. 2, 249--297 (1993; Zbl 0798.57018)]) for the groups \(A_{n}\). Note that this paper is part of a programm aimed to understand equivariant and \(K\)-theoretic invariants for Artin groups (see [\textit{R. Flores} and \textit{J. Gonz√°lez-Meneses}, Int. Math. Res. Not. 2020, No. 5, 1575--1600 (2020; Zbl 1477.20071)]).

title.title: A model structure for locally constant factorization algebras

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: A group homomorphism \(i:H\to G\) is a \textit{localization} of \(H\), if for every homomorphism \(\varphi:H\to G\) there exists a unique endomorphism \(\psi:G\to G\) such that \(i \psi=\varphi\) (maps are acting on the right). \textit{R. G√∂bel} and \textit{J. Trlifaj} asked in [Approximations and endomorphism algebras of modules. 2nd revised and extended ed. Berlin: Walter de Gruyter (2012; Zbl 1292.16001), Problem 30.4(4), p. 831] which abelian groups are centers of localizations of simple groups. Approaching this question we show that every countable abelian group is indeed the center of some localization of a quasi-simple group, i.e., a central extension of a simple group. The proof uses Obraztsov and Ol'shanskii's construction of infinite simple groups with a special subgroup lattice and also extensions of results on localizations of finite simple groups by the second author and \textit{J. Scherer} and \textit{J. Th√©venaz} [Isr. J. Math. 131, 185--202 (2002; Zbl 1010.20007)] and \textit{J. Scherer} and \textit{A. Viruel} [J. Algebra 305, No. 2, 765--774 (2006; Zbl 1109.20046)].

title.title: On localizations of quasi-simple groups with given countable center

editorial_contributions.text:
This article is a contribution to a better understanding of the \(B\mathbb Z/p\)-homotopy theory of classifying spaces. By this we mean that one wishes to understand classifying spaces through the eyes of the mapping space with source \(B\mathbb Z/p\), either by computing the \(B\mathbb Z/p\)-nullification, the space that is left after killing everything that comes from \(B\mathbb Z/p\), or the \(B\mathbb Z/p\)-cellularization, the closest space built out of \(B\mathbb Z/p\) by pointed homotopy colimits.

The second author started this line of investigation in [Trans. Am. Math. Soc. 359, No. 4, 1791--1816 (2007; Zbl 1112.55009)] for classifying spaces of finite groups. The problem with compact Lie groups, finite loop spaces, or even Kac-Moody groups, is that they are not purely torsion. The main result on \(B\mathbb Z/p\)-nullification exhibits its value on all these kinds of classifying spaces as the total space of a fibration where the base space is the classifying space of the quotient of the fundamental group by its \(p\)-radical subgroup and the fiber is the classical \(\mathbb Z[1/p]\)-localization of the classifying space of the corresponding covering space. In particular when dealing with \(p\)-local compact groups, because the fundamental group is a finite \(p\)-group, nullification coincides with \(\mathbb Z[1/p]\)-localization.

The second part of the paper is devoted to cellularization, more precisely to dichotomy results of the following type: The cellularization of \(BG\), where \(G\) is a compact Lie group, is either the classifying space of an elementary abelian \(p\)-group, or it has infinitely many non-trivial homotopy groups. The latter happens if and only if there is a \(p\)-cohomologically central element of order \(p\) in \(G\). When there is no such element, and this is the case for \(S^1\) or \(S^3\) at the prime \(2\), the \(B\mathbb Z/p\)-cellularization is accessible. The challenge is then to provide a good description in more complicated situations. Building on work of the first author [\textit{N. Castellana} et al., Trans. Am. Math. Soc. 359, No. 3, 1099--1113 (2007; Zbl 1110.55006)], using in particular the idea of ``lifting elements'' in the fundamental group, the case of \(p\)-toral groups is analyzed, allowing the authors to describe \(CW_{B\mathbb Z/2} BO(2)\), up to \(2\)-completion. The more exotic example of \(SO(3)\) at the prime \(2\) is also studied in detail.

title.title: Homotopy idempotent functors on classifying spaces

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: In this paper we compute the Bredon homology of wallpaper groups with respect to the family of finite groups and with coefficients in the complex representation ring. We provide explicit bases of the homology groups in terms of irreducible characters of the stabilizers.

series.title: Bulletin of the Korean Mathematical Society

title.title: Bredon homology of wallpaper groups

editorial_contributions.text: The authors define \(\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{cct}}\) as the class of groups \(G\) satisfying the following property: there is a finite family of non-trivial finite cyclic subgroups \(\{G_{\lambda }\}_{\lambda \in \Lambda }\) such that for each non-trivial torsion subgroup \(H\) of \(G,\) there exists a unique \( \lambda \in \Lambda \) and a unique coset \(gG_{\lambda }\in G/G_{\lambda }\) such that \(H\leq gG_{\lambda }g^{-1}.\) The class \(\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{cct}}\) contains groups with aspherical presentations (in the sense defined on p. 275), one-relator products of locally indicable groups, some extensions of \(\mathbb{Z}^{n}\) by cyclic groups and some Fuchsian groups. In the article under review, the authors give a computation of the Bredon homology \(H_{\ast }^{\mathcal{F}}(G;R_{\mathbb{C}})\) of groups in \(\mathcal{G}_{\mathrm{cct}}\) with coefficients in the representation functor \(R_{\mathbb{C}}\). As applications, the Baum-Connes conjecture is confirmed for Hempel groups (for precise definition see Definition 3.1).
