title.title: Generators and closed classes of groups

editorial_contributions.text:
Given pointed spaces \(A\) and \(X\), \(X\) is said to be \(A\)-\textit{cellular} if it can be constructed out of \(A\) by means of (iterated) pointed homotopy colimits. \textit{E. Dror Farjoun} [Cellular spaces, null spaces and homotopy localization. Berlin: Springer-Verlag (1995; Zbl 0842.55001)] proved the existence of an augmented and idempotent functor \(CW_A : \mathbf{Spaces}_*\to\mathbf{Spaces}_*\) such that \(CW_AX\)  is \(A\)-cellular, and the augmentation \(\eta : CW \to \mbox{Id}\) induces a weak equivalence \(\mbox{map}_*(A,CW_AX)\to \mbox{map}_*(A,X)\), for every pointed  space \(X\). The space \(CW_AX\), which is unique up to homotopy, is called the \(A\)-\textit{cellular approximation} or \(A\)-\textit{cellularization} of \(X\). 

Let \(BG\) be the classifying space of an abelian \(p\)-torsion group \(G\). The present paper is a part of a long-term program designed to understand the \(BG\)-cellular approximations of classifying spaces of groups and their mod \(p\) homotopical analogues. The first objects studied in this context were classifying spaces of finite groups. The culminating result of \textit{R. J. Flores} and \textit{R. M. Foote} [Isr. J. Math. 184, 129--156 (2011; Zbl 1271.55013)] uses a previous classification of strongly closed subgroups of finite groups [\textit{R. J. Flores} and \textit{R. M. Foote}, Adv. Math. 222, No. 2, 453--484 (2009; Zbl 1181.20014)], emphasizing the tight relationship between the \(B\mathbb{Z}/p\)-cellular approximation of \(BG\) and the \(p\)-local information of \(G\) (or fusion system at the prime \(p\)). This key observation opened the way to the description of the \(B\mathbb{Z}/p\)-cellular approximation of classifying spaces of \(p\)-local finite groups, 
the mod \(p\) homotopical analogues of classifying spaces of finite groups defined by \textit{C. Broto} et al. [J. Am. Math. Soc. 16, No. 4, 779--856 (2003; Zbl 1033.55010)].

The main goal of this paper is to generalize the mentioned results to the most general framework of \(p\)-local compact groups, defined by \textit{C. Broto} et al. [Geom. Topol. 11, 315--427 (2007; Zbl 1135.55008)] with special emphasis in the cases which arise from compact Lie groups.

editorial_contributions.text:
Given two spaces \(A\) and \(X\), \(X\) is \(A\)-null if the mapping space \(\text{map}(A,X)\) is homotopy equivalent to \(X\) via the inclusion of the constant maps, \(X\hookrightarrow \text{map}(A,X)\). The \(A\)-nullification of a space is a functor on spaces that assigns to \(X\) an \(A\)-null space \(P_A(X)\) together with a universal map \(X\to P_A(X)\) which induces a weak homotopy equivalence \(\text{map}(P_A(X),Y) \simeq \text{map}(X,Y)\) for every \(A\)-null space \(Y\). Thus \(P_A\) `makes trivial the structure of \(X\) that depends on \(A\).'

Let \(G\) denote a discrete group throughout. The paper relates nullification with respect to \(W_\infty = \bigvee_p B\mathbb{Z}_p\), where the index is over the prime numbers, and the classifying space for proper actions of a group \(G\), denoted \(\underline{\text{B}}G\). The space \(\underline{\text{B}}G\) enjoys the universal property that if \(G\) acts on \(X\) with isotropy groups all finite, then there is a \(G\)-map \(X\to \underline{\text{E}}G\) unique up to \(G\) homotopy. The space \(\underline{\text{B}}G = \underline{\text{E}}G/G\). The main theorem shows that \(P_{W_\infty}(BG) \simeq \underline{\text{B}}G\).

Based on this equivalence, the author explores the properties of the classifying space for proper actions. As a functor \(\underline{\text{B}}\) takes products to products, and certain pushouts of groups to the corresponding pushout of classifying spaces. Using the properties of \(\bigvee_p B\mathbb{Z}_p\) and nullification, there are results for the homotopy type of \(\underline{\text{B}}G\) for \(G\) locally finite, supersoluble, or one of the wallpaper groups. Since \(\underline{\text{B}}G\) and \(BG\) are realized as realizations of nerves of small categories, the analysis of \(BG \to \underline{\text{B}}G\) can be studied by simplicial means, and the author determines the homotopy fibre of this map to end the paper.

msc.text: Classifying spaces of groups and \(H\)-spaces in algebraic topology
Localization and completion in homotopy theory

title.title: What is a good result in the first leg of a two-legged football match?

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We propose an alternative geometric mathematical structure for arbitrary phase space. The main guide in our approach is the hidden \(\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb R})\)-symmetry which acts on the phase space changing coordinates by momenta and vice versa. We show that the \(\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb R})\)-symmetry is implicit in any symplectic structure. We also prove that in any sensible physical theory based on the \(\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb R)\)-symmetry the signature of the flat target `spacetime' must be associated with either one-time and one-space or at least two-time and two-space coordinates. We discuss the consequences as well as possible applications of our approach on different physical scenarios.

msc.text: Differential geometric methods, including holonomy, Berry and Hannay phases, Aharonov-Bohm effect, etc. in quantum theory

title.title: \(\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb R)\)-geometric phase space and \((2+2)\)-dimensions

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: This paper shows how the Formal Knot Theory state model for the Alexander-Conway polynomial is related to Knot Floer Homology. In particular, we prove a parity result about the states in this model that clarifies certain relationships of the model with Knot Floer Homology.

editorial_contributions.text: In 1987 skein modules were introduced by Przytycki as invariants of embeddings of co-dimension two, modulo ambient isotopy, which in the case of \(3\)-manifolds generalise quantum invariants of links. In particular, the Kauffman bracket skein modules are generalisations of the Kauffman bracket of links in the sphere \(S^3\). In [Trans. Am. Math. Soc. 352, No. 10, 4877--4888 (2000; Zbl 0951.57007)], \textit{C. Frohman} and \textit{R. Gelca} gave a product-to-sum formula for the Kauffman bracket skein algebra of the thickened torus. The present paper deals with the Kauffman bracket skein algebra of the thickened four-holed sphere for which the authors provide an algorithm to compute the product of any two elements of the algebra, and give an explicit formula for some families of curves. The existence of a positive basis for the algebra is conjectured.

msc.text: Invariants of 3-manifolds (including skein modules, character varieties)

title.title: Mathematical tools for the future: graph theory and graphicable algebras

editorial_contributions.text:
In the present work, the authors show another view of Khovanov cohomology different from the \(n\)-cube procedure but not far from it. The \(n\)-cube procedure has been used before in work of \textit{D. Bar-Natan} [Algebr. Geom. Topol. 2, 337--370 (2002; Zbl 0998.57016)] and many others to compute the Jones polynomial and Khovanov cohomology. The idea of smoothings and parameters are in some way identical.

The authors prove that the potential extreme Khovanov cohomology of a link is the cohomology of the independence simplicial complex of its Lando graph. They also provide a family of knots having as many non-trivial extreme Khovanov cohomology modules as desired, that is, examples of \(H\)-thick knots that are as far from being \(H\)-thin as desired.

The paper starts by a review of the well-known theory given by \textit{M. Khovanov} [Duke Math. J. 101, No. 3, 359--426 (2000; Zbl 0960.57005)] in the end of the last century and how it was developed by Bar Natan by using the \(n\)-cube concept. \textit{O. Viro} in [Fundam. Math. 184, 317--342 (2004; Zbl 1078.57013)] introduced a nice and important view of Khovanov cohomology by using Kauffman's techniques of enhanced states which in my opinion is another missing part of the Khovanov story for link homology. The authors present an overview of the history and ideas of enhanced states and then pass over to the Lando graph of a link diagram that they will use later according to the relations to the Jones polynomial and hence Khovanov cohomology. This fact comes from the independence number. The Jones polynomial can be shown to be the Euler characteristic of Khovanov cohomology and the independence also suggests the formula of Euler characteristic. Here the authors understand that both ideas led to the study extremely Khovanov cohomology in term of this graph.

In Section 2 they present Khovanov cohomology in terms of enhanced states as a first step to their goal, cf. Viro's work [loc. cit.]. In this section they introduce the Lando graph and its cohomology in more details.

In Section 3 the authors refer to the corresponding cochain complex as the Lando cochain complex, and to the corresponding cohomology modules as the Lando cohomology. They also note that the independence number of the Lando graph is the Euler characteristic associated with the Lando cohomology. Theorem 3.2 in [\textit{Y. Bae} and \textit{H. R. Morton}, J. Knot Theory Ramifications 12, No. 3, 359--373 (2003; Zbl 1064.57010)] is given with Theorem 3.3 in [\textit{P. M. G. Manch√≥n},  ibid. 13, No. 2, 277--295 (2004; Zbl 1065.57010)] to find a connection between both enhanced states and the Jones polynomial. Again the authors find two paths for the Jones polynomial as a bigraded Euler characteristic for Khovanov cohomology. On the other hand, the formula for the independence number suggests that each extreme coefficient of the Jones polynomial is the Euler characteristic of a certain homology given in terms of independence vertices of the Lando graph. Both ideas together have led them to a way of understanding the extreme Khovanov cohomology in terms of this graph; in other words, they have obtained a geometric realization of the potential extreme Khovanov cohomology of a link.

Section 4 is on the Lando graph and extreme Khovanov cohomology which is the heart of the work. This section puts a ground to the work of Section 5. The authors prove that the Lando cochain complex is a copy of the potential extreme Khovanov complex, with the degrees shifted by a constant (Theorem 4.4). In this section there is also an example showing how to apply this theorem in order to compute extreme Khovanov cohomology in a practical way. The rest of the paper deals with applications of Theorem 4.4.

In Section 5 the authors construct a simplicial complex whose homology is equal to the cohomology of the Lando ascendant complex of the link diagram \(D\) up to homological shift. Theorem 4.4 implies that the homology of the simplicial complex determines the extreme Khovanov cohomology of the link represented by \(D\). As Lando graphs are bipartite, Theorems 5.1 and 5.2, together with the fact that a simplicial complex \(X\) and its suspension \(S(X)\) have the same homology and cohomology up to a homological shift by 1, provide an algorithm for computing the cohomology of the independence simplicial complex associated with a Lando graph \(G_D\) (or, equivalently, the extreme Khovanov cohomology of the link represented by \(D\)) from the homology of a specific simplicial complex). In addition to Remark 5.4 which is very interesting, the following theorems give a good idea of the results and applications. I really enjoyed this work.

Section 6 is devoted to families of \(H\)-thick knots. The section starts with the fact that there are 249 prime unoriented knots with at most 10 crossings (not counting mirror images). It is known that all but 12 of these knots are \(H\)-thin, that is, their Khovanov cohomology is supported on two adjacent diagonals, in a matrix in which rows are indexed by \(j\) and columns by \(i\). An \(H\)-thick knot is a knot that is not \(H\)-thin. For example, any non-split alternating link is \(H\)-thin, and any adequate non-alternating knot is \(H\)-thick. After some introduction the authors arrive at the following question: Does any oriented link \(L\) have a diagram \(D\) whose associated \(j_{\mathrm{min}}(D)\) equals the minimum value of \(j\) such that \(H_{i,j}(L)\) is non-trivial for at least one value of \(i\)?

The authors show examples of \(H\)-thick knots having any arbitrary number of non-trivial cohomology groups in the non-trivial row of smallest possible index. More precisely, they provide a diagram \(D\) whose row indexed by \(j_{\mathrm{min}}(D)\) is non-trivial, and hence corresponds to the non-trivial row of smallest possible index. Moreover, this row has as many non-trivial cohomology groups as desired. The authors also remark that Theorem 4.4 allows them to compute the extreme Khovanov cohomology of any link diagram \(D\) by considering independently each of the circles appearing in \(s_AD\), since the non-admissible  \(A\)-chords do not take part in the construction of the simplicial complex \(Y_D\) described in Section 5.

title.title: A geometric description of the extreme Khovanov cohomology

editorial_contributions.text: \textit{R. Lipshitz} and \textit{S. Sarkar} [J. Am. Math. Soc. 27, No. 4, 983--1042 (2014; Zbl 1345.57014)] constructed a refinement of Khovanov homology valued in the stable homotopy category. \textit{J. Gonz√°lez-Meneses} et al. [Proc. R. Soc. Edinb., Sect. A, Math. 148, No. 3, 541--557 (2018; Zbl 1428.57006)] constructed a simplicial complex refining Khovanov homology in the extreme quantum grading, i.e., the minimal possible quantum grading where Khovanov homology is nontrivial. The main goal of the paper under review is to prove that the construction of Gonz√°lez-Meneses, Manch√≥n, and Silvero agrees, up to stable homotopy type, in the extreme quantum grading with that of Lipshitz and Sarkar.

editorial_contributions.text: The author proves the title, shows it cannot be extended to higher indices, rebuts the proof of Corollary 88 in [\textit{L. Rudolph}, in: Handbook of knot theory. Amsterdam: Elsevier. 349--427 (2005; Zbl 1097.57012)] and reports how the anonymous referee fixed it by replacing each negative band with a sequence of six positive ones.

title.title: Strongly quasipositive links with braid index 3 have positive Conway polynomial

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We determine the structure of the Khovanov homology groups in homological grading 1 of positive links. More concretely, we show that the first Khovanov homology is supported in a single quantum grading determined by the Seifert genus of the link, where the group is free abelian and of rank determined by the Seifert graph of any of its positive link diagrams. In particular, for a positive link, the first Khovanov homology is vanishing if and only if the link is fibered. Moreover, we extend these results to (p,q)-cables of positive knots whenever $q\geq p$. We also show that several infinite families of Heegaard Floer L-space knots have vanishing first Khovanov homology. This suggests a possible extension of our results to L-space knots.

msc.text: Finite-type and quantum invariants, topological quantum field theories (TQFT)
Homology theories in knot theory (Khovanov, Heegaard-Floer, etc.)

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We give an almost complete classification of Artin groups of spherical type up to commensurability. Let \(A\) and \(A'\) be two Artin groups of spherical type, and let \(A_1,\dots,A_p\) (respectively, \(A'_1,\dots,A'_q)\) be the irreducible components of \(A\) (respectively, \(A')\). We show that \(A\) and \(A'\) are commensurable if and only if \(p=q\) and, up to permutation of the indices, \(A_i\) and \(A'_i\) are commensurable for every \(i\). We prove that, if two Artin groups of spherical type are commensurable, then they have the same rank. For a fixed \(n\), we give a complete classification of the irreducible Artin groups of rank \(n\) that are commensurable with the group of type \(A_n\). Note that there are six remaining comparisons of pairs of groups to get the complete classification of Artin groups of spherical type up to commensurability, two of which have been done by Ignat Soroko after the first version of the present paper.

title.title: Commensurability in Artin groups of spherical type

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We give a short proof for the fact, already proven by Thomas Haettel, that the arbitrary intersection of parabolic subgroups in Euclidean Braid groups $A[\tilde{A}_n]$ is again a parabolic subgroup. To that end, we use that the spherical-type Artin group $A[B_{n+1}]$ is isomorphic to $A[\tilde{A}_n] \rtimes \mathbb{Z}$.

title.title: Intersection of Parabolic Subgroups in Euclidean Braid Groups: a short proof

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: The root extraction problem in braid groups is the following: given a braid $\beta \in \mathcal{B}_n$ and a number $k\in \mathbb{N}$, find $\alpha\in \mathcal{B}_n$ such that $\alpha^k=\beta$. In the last decades, many cryptosystems such as authentication schemes and digital signatures based on the root extraction problem have been proposed. In this paper, we first describe these cryptosystems built around braid groups. Then we prove that, in general, these authentication schemes and digital signature are not secure by presenting for each of them a possible attack.

msc.text: Authentication, digital signatures and secret sharing

title.title: The root extraction problem in braid group-based cryptography

title.title: The root extraction problem for generic braids

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: A Cantor surface $\mathcal C_d$ is a non-compact surface obtained by gluing copies of a fixed compact surface $Y^d$ (a block), with $d+1$ boundary components, in a tree-like fashion. For a fixed subgroup $H<Map(Y^d)$ , we consider the subgroup $\mathfrak B_d(H)<Map(\mathcal C_d)$ whose elements eventually send blocks to blocks and act like an element of $H$; we refer to $\mathfrak B_d(H)$ as the block mapping class group with local action prescribed by $H$. The family of groups so obtained contains the asymptotic mapping class groups of \cite{SW21a,ABF+21, FK04}. Moreover, there is a natural surjection onto the family symmetric Thompson groups of Farley--Hughes \cite{FH15}; in particular, they provide a positive answer to \cite[Question 5.37]{AV20}. We prove that, when the block is a (holed) sphere or a (holed) torus, $\mathfrak B_d(H)$ is of type $F_n$ if and only if $H$ is of type $F_n$. As a consequence, for every $n$, $Map(C_d)$ has a subgroup of type $F_n$ but not $F_{n+1}$ which contains the mapping class group of every compact subsurface of $\mathcal C_d$.

title.title: Block mapping class groups and their finiteness properties

title.title: A new family of infinitely braided Thompson's groups

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We show that pure subgroups of infinitely braided Thompson's are bi-orderable. For every finitely generated pure subgroup, we give explicit sets of generators.

msc.text: Generators, relations, and presentations of groups

title.title: Pure infinitely braided Thompson groups

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: We give a quadratic-time explicit and computable algorithm to solve the word problem for Artin groups that do not contain any relations of length 3. Furthermore, we prove that, given two geodesic words representing the same element, one can obtain one from the other by using a set of homogeneous relations that never increase the word length.

msc.text: Word problems, other decision problems, connections with logic and automata (group-theoretic aspects)

title.title: The Word Problem is Solvable for 3-free Artin groups in Quadratic Time

editorial_contributions.text:
The submodule spanned by \(C_+\), the union of the Hecke algebras in the oriented Homfly skein of the annulus is isomorphic to the algebra of symmetric functions. By utilizing classical properties of the symmetric functions and examining Turaev's basis for \(C_+\) and formulae of \textit{M. Rosso} and \textit{V. Jones} [J. Knot Theory Ramifications 2, No.~1, 97--112 (1993; Zbl 0787.57006)] the authors are able to relate the Homfly satellite invariants of a knot to the quantum \(sl(N)\) invariants of its cables. They obtain a formula for the satellite of a cable as an element of the Homfly skein module. They go on to get relations among Homfly invariants of some diagrams decorated by power sums.

The skein theoretic representatives corresponding to the Schur functions play a central role in the authors' analyses.

msc.text: Quantum groups (quantized function algebras) and their representations

title.title: Geometrical relations and plethysms in the Homfly skein of the annulus

editorial_contributions.text:
In the present work, the authors show another view of Khovanov cohomology different from the \(n\)-cube procedure but not far from it. The \(n\)-cube procedure has been used before in work of \textit{D. Bar-Natan} [Algebr. Geom. Topol. 2, 337--370 (2002; Zbl 0998.57016)] and many others to compute the Jones polynomial and Khovanov cohomology. The idea of smoothings and parameters are in some way identical.

The authors prove that the potential extreme Khovanov cohomology of a link is the cohomology of the independence simplicial complex of its Lando graph. They also provide a family of knots having as many non-trivial extreme Khovanov cohomology modules as desired, that is, examples of \(H\)-thick knots that are as far from being \(H\)-thin as desired.

The paper starts by a review of the well-known theory given by \textit{M. Khovanov} [Duke Math. J. 101, No. 3, 359--426 (2000; Zbl 0960.57005)] in the end of the last century and how it was developed by Bar Natan by using the \(n\)-cube concept. \textit{O. Viro} in [Fundam. Math. 184, 317--342 (2004; Zbl 1078.57013)] introduced a nice and important view of Khovanov cohomology by using Kauffman's techniques of enhanced states which in my opinion is another missing part of the Khovanov story for link homology. The authors present an overview of the history and ideas of enhanced states and then pass over to the Lando graph of a link diagram that they will use later according to the relations to the Jones polynomial and hence Khovanov cohomology. This fact comes from the independence number. The Jones polynomial can be shown to be the Euler characteristic of Khovanov cohomology and the independence also suggests the formula of Euler characteristic. Here the authors understand that both ideas led to the study extremely Khovanov cohomology in term of this graph.

In Section 2 they present Khovanov cohomology in terms of enhanced states as a first step to their goal, cf. Viro's work [loc. cit.]. In this section they introduce the Lando graph and its cohomology in more details.

In Section 3 the authors refer to the corresponding cochain complex as the Lando cochain complex, and to the corresponding cohomology modules as the Lando cohomology. They also note that the independence number of the Lando graph is the Euler characteristic associated with the Lando cohomology. Theorem 3.2 in [\textit{Y. Bae} and \textit{H. R. Morton}, J. Knot Theory Ramifications 12, No. 3, 359--373 (2003; Zbl 1064.57010)] is given with Theorem 3.3 in [\textit{P. M. G. Manch√≥n},  ibid. 13, No. 2, 277--295 (2004; Zbl 1065.57010)] to find a connection between both enhanced states and the Jones polynomial. Again the authors find two paths for the Jones polynomial as a bigraded Euler characteristic for Khovanov cohomology. On the other hand, the formula for the independence number suggests that each extreme coefficient of the Jones polynomial is the Euler characteristic of a certain homology given in terms of independence vertices of the Lando graph. Both ideas together have led them to a way of understanding the extreme Khovanov cohomology in terms of this graph; in other words, they have obtained a geometric realization of the potential extreme Khovanov cohomology of a link.

Section 4 is on the Lando graph and extreme Khovanov cohomology which is the heart of the work. This section puts a ground to the work of Section 5. The authors prove that the Lando cochain complex is a copy of the potential extreme Khovanov complex, with the degrees shifted by a constant (Theorem 4.4). In this section there is also an example showing how to apply this theorem in order to compute extreme Khovanov cohomology in a practical way. The rest of the paper deals with applications of Theorem 4.4.

In Section 5 the authors construct a simplicial complex whose homology is equal to the cohomology of the Lando ascendant complex of the link diagram \(D\) up to homological shift. Theorem 4.4 implies that the homology of the simplicial complex determines the extreme Khovanov cohomology of the link represented by \(D\). As Lando graphs are bipartite, Theorems 5.1 and 5.2, together with the fact that a simplicial complex \(X\) and its suspension \(S(X)\) have the same homology and cohomology up to a homological shift by 1, provide an algorithm for computing the cohomology of the independence simplicial complex associated with a Lando graph \(G_D\) (or, equivalently, the extreme Khovanov cohomology of the link represented by \(D\)) from the homology of a specific simplicial complex). In addition to Remark 5.4 which is very interesting, the following theorems give a good idea of the results and applications. I really enjoyed this work.

Section 6 is devoted to families of \(H\)-thick knots. The section starts with the fact that there are 249 prime unoriented knots with at most 10 crossings (not counting mirror images). It is known that all but 12 of these knots are \(H\)-thin, that is, their Khovanov cohomology is supported on two adjacent diagonals, in a matrix in which rows are indexed by \(j\) and columns by \(i\). An \(H\)-thick knot is a knot that is not \(H\)-thin. For example, any non-split alternating link is \(H\)-thin, and any adequate non-alternating knot is \(H\)-thick. After some introduction the authors arrive at the following question: Does any oriented link \(L\) have a diagram \(D\) whose associated \(j_{\mathrm{min}}(D)\) equals the minimum value of \(j\) such that \(H_{i,j}(L)\) is non-trivial for at least one value of \(i\)?

The authors show examples of \(H\)-thick knots having any arbitrary number of non-trivial cohomology groups in the non-trivial row of smallest possible index. More precisely, they provide a diagram \(D\) whose row indexed by \(j_{\mathrm{min}}(D)\) is non-trivial, and hence corresponds to the non-trivial row of smallest possible index. Moreover, this row has as many non-trivial cohomology groups as desired. The authors also remark that Theorem 4.4 allows them to compute the extreme Khovanov cohomology of any link diagram \(D\) by considering independently each of the circles appearing in \(s_AD\), since the non-admissible  \(A\)-chords do not take part in the construction of the simplicial complex \(Y_D\) described in Section 5.

title.title: A geometric description of the extreme Khovanov cohomology

editorial_contributions.text:
The bracket polynomial of a link diagram \(D\) is defined by 
\[
\langle D\rangle =\sum_s\langle D,s\rangle,\quad \langle D,s\rangle = A^{a(s)-b(s)}(-A^2 - A^{-2})^{|s|-1}
\]
 where the sum is taken over all states \(s\) of \(D\) and \(|s|\) denotes the number of the circles remaining after splicing the crossings according to the state \(s\) as usual. The extreme states \(s_A\) and \(s_B\) of \(D\) are the states in which all crossings are labelled \(A\) and all are labelled \(B\), respectively. The extreme coefficients \(a_m\) and \(a_M\) of \(D\) are the coefficients of the terms of the extreme degrees \(m = \min(s_B)\) and \(M = \max(s_A)\), respectively, where for a state \(s\), \(\min(s)\) and \(\max(s)\) denote the lowest and highest, respectively, degrees of \(\langle D,s\rangle\).

 In section 2, the author generalizes some results obtained by \textit{Y. Bae} and \textit{H. R. Morton} [J. Knot Theory Ramifications 12, 359--373 (2003; Zbl 1064.57010)] and finds a family of prime diagrams of knots with arbitrary extreme coefficients in their Jones polynomials.

 In section 3, the author constructs graphs, from which the knot diagrams with fewer crossings can be made, and in section 4, the author exhibits nice examples of prime diagrams of knots for which the extreme coefficients are zero and the next coefficients take arbitrary values.

 The author closes by asking the following question: how arbitrary can the extreme coefficients of the Jones polynomial be when the value for the spread is previously fixed?

msc.text: Planar graphs; geometric and topological aspects of graph theory

title.title: Pretzel knots up to nine crossings

editorial_contributions.text:
This paper concerns the Seifert matrix associated with the projection surface for a homogeneous link. Here, the projection surface is the Seifert surface obtained by applying the Seifert algorithm to a diagram of the link. Homogeneous links were introduced by \textit{P. R. Cromwell} [J. Lond. Math. Soc., II. Ser. 39, No. 3, 535--552 (1989; Zbl 0685.57004)] and are defined to be links which have a homogeneous diagram. A diagram is homogeneous if in each block of its Seifert graph all the edges have the same sign, where a block of a graph is a maximal subgraph which has no cut-vertex. Alternating links and positive links are homogeneous.

The main theorem asserts that for a connected diagram of an oriented link there is a basis for the first homology group of the projection surface with which the Seifert matrix is expressed as a lower block triangular form. The basis is divided into groups corresponding to the decomposition of the Seifert graph into blocks. Precisely, let \(G\) denote the Seifert graph and let \(G=B_{1}\cup\dots\cup B_{k}\) be the decomposition of \(G\) into blocks. Then if \(M_{i}\) is the Seifert matrix that corresponds to any basis of \(H_{1}(B_{i})\) the Seifert matrix takes the form that the \(M_{i}\)'s line in the diagonal by reordering the \(B_{i}\)'s appropriately and every entry above the block-diagonal is zero. Applying the main theorem to homogeneous links the author gives an alternative proof of the theorem of Cromwell, which asserts that for a connected homogeneous diagram of an oriented homogeneous link \(L\), the highest degree of the Conway polynomial \(\nabla_{L}(z)\) is equal to the rank of the Seifert graph. Moreover, suppose that \(G=B_{1}\cup\dots\cup B_{k}\) and \(M_{i}\;(i=1, 2, \dots , k) \) are as above, the leading coefficient of \(\nabla_{L}(z)\) is equal to \(\prod_{i=1}^{k}\epsilon_{i}^{r_{i}}|\det M_{i}|\), where \(\epsilon_{i}\) is the sign of the edges in \(B_{i}\) and \(r_{i}\) is the rank of \(B_{i}\). As a corollary, it is reproved that a projection surface obtained from a connected homogeneous diagram of an oriented link is a minimal-genus spanning surface for the link.

The proof of the main theorem is geometric and based on the close relation between the Seifert matrix and the decomposition into blocks of the Seifert graph. Since the homogeneous block \(B_{i}\) corresponds to an alternating diagram, by the work of \textit{K. Murasugi} [J. Math. Soc. Japan 10, 94--105 (1958; Zbl 0084.19301); ibid. 235--248 (1958; Zbl 0106.16701); Osaka Math. J. 12, 277--303 (1960; Zbl 0113.38603)] and \textit{R. H. Crowell} [Ann. Math. (2) 69, 258--275 (1959; Zbl 0111.35803)] the Seifert matrix \(M_{i}\) has nonzero determinant. As an alternative treatment, the author looks into an explicit form of matrices which reflects the planar structure of the Seifert graph.

title.title: Homogeneous links and the Seifert matrix

editorial_contributions.text:
The paper under review studies the relation of simple braids and the so called Morton-Franks-Williams inequality. If \( T(\alpha)\) is a simple braid having permutation \(\alpha\) and \(\hat T(\alpha)\) denotes the closure of the braid \( T(\alpha)\), then the authors show:

Proposition 2.1. Let \(\alpha\in S_n\) be a permutation with length \(w=\ell(\alpha)\). Then \(\partial_v^{+}(P(\hat T_{\alpha}))=w+n-1\) if and only if \(\alpha=id\), and the coefficient of \(v^{w+n-1}\) in \(P(\hat T_{id})\) is \((-z)^{1-n}\).

This is the main result of the paper, which appears in Section 2, and in the remaining three sections the authors use the result above to obtain several applications. In Section 3 they reprove the following result:

Theorem 3.1 (K√°lm√°n):

 The set of simple braids \(\{T_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha\in S_n}\) is an orthonormal basis for \(< .\;,\;. >_R\).

In Section 4 the authors consider the concept of simple resolution tree and the main result is to say when the closure of a braid satisfies the Morton-Franks-Williams inequality in terms of its simple resolution tree. Namely:

Theorem 4.1: Let \(L=\hat b\) be a link obtained as the closure of a positive braid \(b\) of \(n\) strands and writhe \(w\). Then \(b\) admits a simple resolution tree and, moreover, the Morton-Franks-Williams upper bound is sharp for \(L\), that is, \(\partial_v^+(P(L))=w+n-1\), if and only if at least one leaf in this simple resolution tree is the identity braid.

Then several results in form of corollaries are derived. In Section 5 the authors study the braid index of the closure of positive braids on 3 strands. The main result is Theorem 5.1 where they describe, up to cyclic permutation, for which positive words the closure of the corresponding braid have braid index less than three. More precisely they show that this is the case if and only if the positive word \(w\) is one of the words: {\parindent=6mm\begin{itemize}\item[1-] \(\sigma_1\sigma_2^p \;or \;\sigma_2\sigma_1^p,\text{ for }p\geq 0,\) \item[2-] \(\sigma_1\sigma_2 \sigma_1^p\sigma_2^q \text{ or } \sigma_2\sigma_1 \sigma_2^p\sigma_1^q. \) 

\end{itemize}}

title.title: Closures of positive braids and the Morton-Franks-Williams inequality

editorial_contributions.text:
For a crossing in a link diagram \(D\) we can define two types of `smoothing'; \(A\)-smoothing and \(B\)-smoothing, which were used by \textit{L. H.~Kauffman} to define the Jones polynomial [Topology 26, 395--407 (1987; Zbl 0622.57004)]. Let \(s_A(D)\) (\(s_B(D)\), respectively) be the circles that appear when one changes each crossing by \(A\)-smoothing (\(B\)-smoothing, respectively), and let \(|s_A(D)|\) (\(|s_B(D)|\), respectively) be the number of circles in \(s_A(D)\) (\(s_B(D)\), respectively). One can make an alternating diagram by changing several crossings if necessary. If the least number of such crossings, which are called dealternators, is \(k\), the diagram is called \(k\)-almost alternating. Let \(D_i\) be the diagram obtained from a \(k\)-almost alternating diagram \(D\) by smoothing all the dealternators in some way (\(i=1,2,\dots,2^k\)). The diagram \(D\) is called dealternator connected (dealternator reduced, respectively) if \(D_i\) is connected (reduced, respectively) for any \(i\), cf. \textit{C. C. Adams} et al. [Topology Appl. 46, No.~2, 151--165 (1992; Zbl 0766.57003)]. 

The authors construct a surface of genus \(k\) with \(k\) boundary components from a \(k\)-almost alternating diagram \(D\), and prove a formula for \(|s_A(D)+|s_B(D)|\). In particular, if the diagram is dealternator connected and has \(n\) crossings, the equality \(|s_A(D)|+|s_B(D)|=n+2-2k\) follows. As a corollary the authors obtain an upper bound of the span of the Jones polynomial by \textit{J.~Zhou} [J. Knot Theory Ramifications 6, No.~1, 125--148 (1997; Zbl 0878.57014)].

They also show a similar result for the case where a diagram is dealternator connected and dealternator reduced and a relation to the Turaev genus (the genus of a surface appearing as a cobordism from \(s_A(D)\) and \(s_B(D)\)) of a dealternator connected diagram, \textit{O. T. Dasbach}, et al. [J. Comb. Theory, Ser. B 98, No.~2, 384--399 (2008; Zbl 1135.05015)], \textit{V. G. Turaev} [Enseign. Math., II. Ser. 33, 203--225 (1987; Zbl 0668.57009)]).

references.text: Adams C. C., An Elementary Introduction to the Mathematical Theory of Knots, in: The Knot Book (1994)
Turaev V. G., L'Enseignement Math. 33 pp 203--

title.title: A geometric characterization of the upper bound for the span of the Jones polynomial

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: If two permutations are strongly conjugate, then their corresponding positive permutation braids (also called simple braids) are conjugate. In this paper we exhibit two conjugate simple braids whose associated permutations are not strongly conjugate. In terms of the grey and black graphs with vertices in the ultra summit set defined by \textit{J. S. Birman, V. Gebhardt} and \textit{J. Gonz√°lez Meneses} [Conjugacy in Garside groups. II (arXiv math.GT0606652)], this result can be reformulated by saying that there are ultra summit sets with simple braids (hence with canonical length \(k=1\)) in which the grey graph is not connected. Birman, Gebhardt and Gonz√°lez Meneses have given similar examples, but with \(k\geqslant 2\) [loc. cit.]. Recall that the set of simple braids on \(n\) strings is a basis of the Hecke algebra \(H_n\). If two simple braids on \(n\) strings are conjugate, the associated permutations are centrally conjugate, which means that the coefficients of any central element of \(H_n\) corresponding to these simple braids are equal. Working on topological dynamics, \textit{T. Hall} and \textit{A. de Carvalho} [private communication] have discovered two braids on 12 strings (one and its reverse) which are not conjugate. Since one braid is the reverse of the other, their corresponding permutations are centrally conjugate. For \(n\leqslant 6\) we checked that central conjugacy implies conjugacy of the corresponding simple braids.

msc.text: Knots and links in high dimensions (PL-topology)

source.source: Math. Proc. Camb. Philos. Soc. 143, No. 3, 663-667 (2007).

title.title: There exist conjugate simple braids whose associated permutations are not strongly conjugate.

editorial_contributions.text:
Alexander proved in 1923 that every link is the closure of a braid. A combinatorial proof of this fact follows from the work by \textit{S. Yamada} [Invent. Math. 89, 347--356 (1987; Zbl 0634.57004)], \textit{P. Vogel} [Comment. Math. Helv. 65, No. 1, 104--113 (1990; Zbl 0703.57004)] and \textit{P. Traczyk} [Banach Cent. Publ. 42, 409--419 (1998; Zbl 0901.57018)]. Given integers \(a_1,a_2,\dots,a_n\), denote by \(P(a_1,a_2,\dots,a_n)\) a pretzel link diagram, in general with \(n\) columns with \(|a_i|\) crossings in each one. 

In the paper under review, the authors give a procedure that provides, given an unoriented pretzel link \(L\), a braid whose closure is \(L\). Furthermore, they give a braid word in terms of the pretzel link. They define certain moves to convert the pretzel diagram into a closed braid. The braids obtained using this procedure are far from being minimal with respect to the number of crossings, but in many cases they are minimal with respect to the number of strands. Recently, \textit{L. Lewark} [``Quasipositivity and braid index of pretzel knots'', Preprint, \url{arXiv:2205.05347}] has proved that the braids provided in this paper for the pretzel knots \(P(p, q, -2r)\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are odd integers different from \(\pm 1\) and \(r\) is a nonzero integer, are minimal with respect to the number of strands.

source.source: J. Knot Theory Ramifications 31, No. 14, Article ID 2250089, 16 p. (2022).

title.title: Braids for unoriented pretzel links

editorial_contributions.text: Summary: Totally included framed links are defined and an algorithm for moving these links to Lickorish's framed links is given by means of a refinement of the Fundamental Theorem of Surgery on 3-manifolds. This technique is applied to the simple chains or brackets.
